If Europeans want more Europe, it is to build a social project and not only to adopt even more technical guidelines.
Regulation concerning the domestic market is certainly necessary, but it is not, and by far, the essential.
The 2009 program, like the previous ones, will pass by the subject.
Citizens do not expect the Commission to complete or even simplify the legislation
They expect the Commission to be at the level of the task assigned to it by the treaties, the locomotive, the idea box of the Union.

We expect the Commission to act as a key player in the reflection on the nature of the social project we need

of the high-level conference on Georgia that had been proposed by the French presidency and how the current presidency of the Union intends to defend the territorial integrity of Georgia while a country recognizes two separatist regions, Abkhazia and the South Ossetia.
But it's a shame that Mr Barroso is not here because in his speech he was not convincing, maybe because he himself is not convinced by the proposals he made to us.
I think the financial and economic situation is much more serious than he described it to us.
And today again, I think that those who follow the Internet see very well that the stock exchanges continue to collapse despite the interventions.

For me, it is the collapse of the current system, a completely obsolete system, the system that led to the bankruptcy, that led a land to be completely exploited and suffocated by greenhouse gas emissions, that led to the poor development in the south and in our cities.
I thank you, Madam President, Madam Commissioner. The current financial crisis shows that when the problem is global, a global action is needed.
This is true especially in the field of agriculture or in the food sector.
This is why we created the World Trade Organization, on which we agree, which tries to have planetary rules.

It turns out that it doesn't work quite as we would like because we are facing a problem which is the following. We have to consider two things. The free trade necessary, on which everyone agrees, but the protections also necessary.
and the protections of economies or national agriculture, that does not mean protectionism.
To do so, the path we have taken for 60 years, since the GATT, is an unbalanced path that goes from reducing customs rights with the objective of their suppression.
Technically, the reduction of customs
It's difficult. The proof? A whole series of mathematical formulas, the South Korean formula, the European formula, or the most famous formula, the Swiss formula.
It doesn't really work because a product is not unitary
It is composed of many elements with very different rules of origin and technically reducing customs rights is not as simple as we think.
We are therefore in a technical impasse and we are trying to get out of this impasse through political negotiations.
However, technologically, scientists have invented a new customs technology, the deductible customs law technology, deductible by the exporter on the economy of the importer state.
Concretely, this deductible customs law is transformed into a customs credit equal to the amount of customs law that the exporter has supported in the importer country.
This credit, which has three characters, is refundable, negotiable and charitable.
It is refundable when the exporter buys from the importer. He can deduct the customs right he has borne.
It is negotiable because if the exporter who has supported 100 of customs rights has nothing to buy from the importer, she negotiates her customs credit on the stock market or in the bank.
and it is profitable if we want to help countries in the development path, the importer, to offer a loan amount of credit higher than the amount of customs rights.
Well, with this technique, we create an international trade currency whose monetary mass is equal to the amount of existing customs rights.
For example, the European Union would offer 13 billion euros of international currency in the trade sector.

Thank you Mr President. The Russian-Georgian conflict, the financial crisis, have been an opportunity for the European Union to assert itself on the global stage as a full-fledged political actor and of the first order.
Thanks to your determination, Mr. President of the Council, Europe has managed to unite and find coordinated, efficient and fast responses
In the face of crises, Europe proves that it exists and demonstrates its added value.
In immigration, for example, the one-for-all was no longer a season,
the adoption by the European Council of the Pact on Immigration and Asylum initiated by the French Presidency constitutes a considerable advance.
On the fight against climate change, Europe must set concrete goals and show the way to its global partners.

You have already expressed your opinion on this subject, Mr. President of the Council, but we wish that this agreement is as balanced as possible, because it must take into account the economic situation of our countries, which is currently very unstable.
but also to ask ourselves the question of the type of development we will choose for the future.
To meet the challenges they face, the European Union needs the Lisbon Treaty more than ever.
We understand the concerns of our Irish friends, but the Statu quo is not an option.
Ireland must offer us a solution during the European Council in December. Many of us are asking for it.
These last few weeks, we have seen with pride that a strong political Europe, united in adversity, determined to listen to its partners on the international stage.
We hope that this new European mentality becomes the rule and that it persists
The Treaty of Lisbon is the best solution we have to achieve this.
Thank you, Madam President. Mr. Minister, I was in Tbilisi when President Sarkozy came to negotiate the peace plan. And of course, I pay tribute to him for having acted quickly and stopped this war.
But this war is a bit of a failure. We have been shown to be frivolous for 14 years. We have silently assisted the escalation of provocations in separatist regions.

and this war has certainly awakened Europe by placing it in front of its responsibilities. But the fire continues to burn in the Caucasus and we must put everything into practice to definitely resolve the frozen conflicts for the security of all of Europe.
And I also know the divisions, Mr. Minister, of the European countries on the entry of Georgia into NATO. And personally, I am against it.
And I will make you a proposal. I will ask the European Union to propose the status of neutrality for these Caucasian countries.
and only the status of neutrality will be able to calm tensions with Russia and prevent this sub-region from new conflicts.
This status will ensure the security of these young democracies and will contribute to our own security.
Mr. Minister, these last three days have been called the European Development Days, when we have mentioned abundantly the food crisis that seriously affects the poorest countries
The interventions have all insisted on the absolute necessity for developing countries to develop their own agriculture by optimally using their land and natural resources.

By the way, the lyrical flings of those who called yesterday and today again to the reduction of the intervention of the State and of public spending, to the liberalization of all the azimuths, to privatization, to the relegation of agriculture as a
almost prehistoric activity, this turn of events in favor of massive public investment in agricultural production and food sovereignty, all this with something both cockeyed and scandalous.
The future of agriculture in developing countries has a direct relation with the debate we have today.

Unfortunately, I do not feel that this health assessment of the PAC initiated before the paroxysm of the end of hunger and the disastrous disorders of the markets takes into account the situation of the southern peasantry and takes all the consequences of the serious risks that we know today, ecological, social, economic and financial.

I deeply regret that the strong relationship between the North and the South is so little addressed, both in the Commission's proposals and in the Parliament's report. The re-trial of the promised billion euros shows how far the road is still long.
Thank you Mr President. The report we will vote tomorrow marks the end of a year of work and negotiations devoted to the future of the common agricultural policy and our farmers.
Indeed, it was on November 20 that Mrs. Fischer-Bowl came to make her proposals for the health report.
After the report of the tables of the Utz Goebbels, here is the report of Capula-Santos on the proposal of the Commission.
We must congratulate our two colleagues for their excellent work.
The European Parliament's Agriculture Commission has remained firm in its view of the Commission's starting proposal, which we have considered far too liberal.
I will remain vigilant regarding the dairy sector and in particular the measures preceding the abandonment of quotas.

I am thinking in particular of the mountain milk producers, who should not be the poor parents of this reform and we must make sure that we do not leave them alone, because they will need to be more supported than the others.
I don't want to play the Cassandre, but how can we imagine the French dairy industry grouped together in one single region?
I kindly welcome the proposal to set up a milk fund, which will evaluate, from 2010, the increase in dairy prices, according to the market's evolution.

The calculation of the progressive modulation made by the Commission of Agriculture seems fair to me. It would allow us to strengthen the development of territories, rural areas and to sustainably preserve biodiversity.
I also congratulate the clarification of the eco-conditionality, whose implementation was until then a real headache for farmers.

I also hope that we will keep the amount of the tobacco fund that allows us to keep our small exports in Europe as well as a non-negligible labor force in a region where nothing else is exploitable and that allows us to avoid imported products.
Finally, Mr. Minister, we have greatly appreciated your commitment throughout these negotiations.
You have been able to show a lot of passion and determination and you have not counted your time far from being wasted.
It was a real pleasure to work alongside you
you will have been very effective with us.
I know we can count on you
Mr President, first of all, thank you for the work done and for the conclusions and guidelines proposed by the PAC health report of Mr Cabulos Santos.
Agriculture is indeed an economic sector that cannot respond to the simple market signals.
Its activity has impacts on food self-sufficiency, but also, and we see it too often, on the territories and on employment.
The removal of market instruments would be a serious cost to our agriculture
For example, the decoupling of the land is a real difficulty for some farming areas, cattle farms and wine. I am delighted to have heard Mrs. Fischer-Bolle speak on this issue.
Moreover, it is clear that the strict maintenance of historical references would put a huge brake on any possibility of reform.
However, I still believe that the question of the second pillar of the PAC is an essential question because rural areas need to rely on agricultural activity to develop employment in the rural world.
So we must consider this issue without, of course, amputating the first one.
Since Minister Jouyens is leaving us, I think this Parliament should thank him

Mr. President, Mr. Minister, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, Our group enthusiastically supports the Small Business Act project that the Commission presented to us last June.

Certainly, since the 2000s, initiatives have been taken in the direction of PME and I think in particular of the excellent work of our colleague Dominique Blasto on the PME charter. Initiatives that have been appreciated but considered insufficient because they remained too often in the state of vespers.
Today we must go further
The serious economic crisis that our countries are going through and whose consequences are particularly worrying for SMEs, invites us to do so if we need to.
In this respect, the Small Business Act is part of a new, resolutely voluntary approach.
In a few weeks, we will examine the report of Mrs Herzog on the communication of the Commission, but today, through the deposit of this oral question, we have wished to question the Council.
Mr. Minister, we have learned with interest the conclusions adopted yesterday by the Council on Competitiveness and we would like to know if the European Council, from December 11 and 12 next,
will relay its conclusions and will give a strong impetus so that the great principle of the director, think small first, is quickly transposed in the regulatory framework of the Member States.
We hope that the Council will commit to the principle of the action plan which is annexed, with concrete measures.
In this regard, and in the short time that is given to me, I would insist on three directions in which we need restrictive impulses.
Impact studies, which should be systematic and regularly monitored, with the control of the European Parliament, the application of the Small Business Act in Member States,
access to public markets,
The code of conduct has no restrictive scope. Together we must be more imaginative, more inventive and that we propose concrete, adapted measures that really open the access of these markets to SMEs.
Finally, access to funding, more essential than ever in the current context,
Your proposals are good, Mr. Minister, they must also include the support to the offer.
There is urgency
Thank you for assuring us of the will of the Council.

Mr. President, Mr. Minister, Mr. Commissioner, we all know that SMEs are the backbone of the European Union, since they employ more than 70% of the European Union's workforce and represent 99% of European companies.

But as has already been said, these millions of small and medium-sized businesses are now worried and threatened by the financial crisis because it is degrading the purchasing power and the trust of the households, impacting the order lists.
The treasury of SMEs is therefore in danger and therefore it is necessary to ensure that banks guarantee effective access to the necessary financing for the continuity of their operation.
This is the whole issue of the conclusions of the competitiveness council of December 1, which the minister spoke about, and the recovery plan approved by the European ministers of finance.
Making the needs of SMEs a permanent political priority of the Union is essential and I would like to salute the action plan in favour of the Small Business Act for Europe.
It translated the will to ensure the effective application of the principle of the director, to give priority to the small firsts, that is to say to the European SMEs.
However, as the Commissioner said, and as we all say, the Council really engages with the other institutions
European Union, for this principle to be now made effective, we must cross the threshold of the declaration, we must move on to implementation in all policies and all European programs.
However, we can say that this action plan is a real response to the emergency of the situation.
And I would like to thank the French President for his willingness to translate the intentions into action.

Mr. President, Mrs. President, Mr. Commissioner, I give my full support to the rapporteur who defends the position that was ours in the first reading, a position rejected by the governments of the Member States.
It was urgent to put our legislation on the time of guard in accordance with the jurisprudence of the Court of Justice.
The CERCAS report provides balanced and protective answers for the employees.
all the time to be kept and counted as working time

It is a matter of common sense to guarantee decent working conditions, especially for medical professions.
But the reform of the Directive on Work Time also gives us the opportunity to make our European social rights progress by eliminating individual opt-out.
The Serkaz report takes this opportunity and proposes a progressive removal of any possibility of deregulation at the maximum legal duration of the working hours.
We must look at reality from the other side
It is a mockery to say that the employee is in a situation of equal to equal with his employer and can refuse what is proposed to him.
Dear colleagues, we must clearly show the Member States' government that the text they want to impose on us is unacceptable.

And in the concert of praise that will certainly pierce the ears of the French government tomorrow, it seems necessary to focus on the employees, who will be called to work more and more, without really having a choice, and this, like all those who will be asked tomorrow to work on Sunday in France.
It is to open this possibility that the French government has changed its point of view on individual opt-out in the Council.

My dear colleagues, let us listen to the employees and try to respond to their appeal. If we do not want the negative votes of the French, Dutch and Irish referendums to be followed by many others, we are questioning the European Union, which would give them the feeling that they are not dealing with their daily problems. Thank you.
Thank you Mr President. It was a very beautiful French presidency.
There were very few discordant voices to not agree.
The 27 have gone beyond their divergence to reach a series of exemplary decisions.
On the climate package, Europe is taking a first step and this first step is huge.
It now has the means to assume its environmental responsibility without sacrificing its economy
It can now take leadership in this area to lead the other continents on the path to sustainable development.
Moreover, Ireland proposes a scenario to get out of its isolation
Our Irish friends will speak again on the Lisbon Treaty with all the cards in hand since practically all the other members will definitely speak.
The current crises show us that the Union needs the best institutional tools to be effective.
The European Council adopted a massive and coordinated economic recovery plan based on long-term productive investment and the most heavily affected industrial sectors.
President Sarkozy raised the issue of the reduction of some VAT rates and I totally share his point of view.
We hope that the Ministers of Economy and Finance will reach an agreement in March that seemed impossible to the heads of state and government last weekend.
The challenges that Europeans face give the Union the opportunity to reveal itself more united, more reactive, more concerned to protect them.
We are grateful to the French Presidency for having inflated this new dynamic
We wish, as Nicolas Sarkozy, not to see again as soon as yesterday's Council, which ended at 4 a.m. to negotiate three peanuts.
Over the last six months, Europe has changed its mentality, its arrogance, its credibility,
We must thank the French Presidency for this. We are well aware that she is not quite foreign. Thank you, Mr. President.
The situation in Gaza is known to everyone.
that we are discussing here in Parliament is natural.

But we ask that the Security Council take a stand. We ask that the institutions take a stand. We ask that the European Union take a stand. And we, in Parliament, we are discussing and we do not want to take a stand.

I think that, in the face of the urgent situation in Gaza, it is extremely important that this Parliament speak up and say exactly what it wants to stop the massacres that are taking place in the Middle East at this time.
I find it unacceptable that this Parliament does not have the courage and the lucidity to vote a resolution after our debate.
This is why our group is asking to review the decision of the Conference of Presidents and to end the debate that we must have
on the situation in Gaza by a resolution that will demonstrate the clear and firm position of this Parliament, of a majority, so that it stops the massacres in Gaza.

We want a resolution. We must be aware that we have a political responsibility to face what is happening. And this political responsibility cannot be simply a discussion. It must be a resolution that clearly says what we want and what we denounce.
Mr President, Mr Commissioner, more than ever, the proposal of the directive that the Parliament is about to vote for, evokes in me a very mixed feeling.
It is true that reporter Mr. Clins has been doing a long-term work for years and that he negotiated with talent, especially during the trilingual.

It is also true that the Directive knows a number of significant advances in the sense of better functioning of the domestic market, collective management of financial assets and is as such praised by the European investment fund industry.

It remains that the debates and discussions in the Council and Parliament have never been completely free, since the result was known in advance. For some actors, it was necessary at all costs to introduce the European passport for management companies.
On the principle, there is nothing to say, the passport defends itself, absolutely. Still, it is necessary to ensure that the introduction of the passport for management companies
with the necessary guarantees, especially in the matter of fundraising supervision, since it leads to a dissociation of functions beyond the borders.
However, I notice with regret that the system is not only complex, but that it is subject to divergent interpretations,
they will soon run into practical difficulties that will harm the European industry, especially in terms of export to third-country countries.
I have taken into account my position as a minority, yet I do not feel uncomfortable.
Normally, I would have tried to say that only the path of the law will allow us to draw definitive conclusions in this matter and therefore determine
Who is right between those who trust the adaptation faculties of market actors and those who hold to a more cautious approach?
It is not excluded that success is at the end, but on the other hand, nothing guarantees it either.
However, the very recent news, in particular the Madoff scandal and its implications on the collective management of financial assets, is not enough to reassure us.
My worry is succeeded by the scepticism.
The investment fund industry will not be spared by the financial crisis, we have seen it already.
It is possible that fundamental questions should be raised, that from this crisis context

because in these contexts of profound crisis, we would have to make choices that dilute the responsibilities of the actors or that presuppose a perfect cooperation between the authorities of control, which could really lead to an incongruity.
I tell you, as I think, this directive is also that of a revolutionary period before the crisis.
It is marked by a certain carelessness.
Indeed, the financial system will go through a lasting and fundamental crisis. Entire parts of its architecture will be rethought.

Let us not forget the primary function of the OPCM and the protection of the investor by diversifying risks and establishing strict rules. By voting this text in the state without really knowing where we are going, we are acting as if nothing had happened.
This autism is not good, that's why I will abstain even if I sign the compromises agreements negotiated with the Council.
Given the circumstances, the improvements made seem to me to be of little importance in the face of the questions of principles that I have just explained.

Mr President, although the animal report regulation has been in force since January 2007, it seems that member states are not systematically regulated by providing, as they were asked, annual reports.
Also, a global analysis remains random since many elements are missing in terms of the means used to carry out inspections.
Members of the Animal Protection Association and members of the Animal Defense Intergroup, this subject concerns me in particular.
Associations have been desperately fighting for decades, only to finally in 2007 establish directives in this area, where we see that member states display a certain laxity.
I would even dare to say a certain bad will. Because finally, we know it, the implementation of control and inspection is absolutely not insurmountable.
We know the places of slaughter, we know the places of breeding, we know the ways of transit of cattle. So where is the problem?

I believe that it is important in our time when public opinion is increasingly sensitized, rightly so, by the animal condition, whether it is in terms of farming, slaughter or transport conditions, that the States respect these feelings.

And since I have been given the floor, I would like to add concerning transports that it would be essential to consider and take into account, regardless of the duration of transport, the local climatic conditions.
Indeed, a transport of several hours carried out in the Netherlands in the spring has nothing to do with the same amount of transport in the summer in a country such as Greece.
Shouldn't we impose in these last cases night transports?
I thank you for considering this proposal in the future.
Mr President, I am delighted that it is a Brit who has submitted this text, as what the Roman soldiers 2000 years ago did to go to Great Britain and bring oil and wine.
But then, we will have to draw two consequences.
It is not very reasonable to put the food agency in Helsinki. And it is not reasonable that the European Commission does not go back to the following points. First, to restore aid for the homeless.

stop the aggression against the olive trees in the Andalusia and all over Europe, stop the aggression against the red-tinted fishermen in the Mediterranean, and stop the aggression against the European vineyard with the tearing of the trees.
I suggest to our commissioner, our president, Mr Barroso, to organize a big banquet in Portugal with cheese and wine from Portugal.
Thank you Mr President, we all fought for the closure of Guantanamo and we are all happy with the decision of President Obama to close this prison of shame.
Today, the question of welcoming Guantanamo prisoners should not be our question.
As Europeans, loyal to our values of defending the rights of the individual, we must take our responsibilities, because it is our duty to welcome these former detainees.
And we read, and here I am addressing the Council, we read in the press that member states were not very warm for this reception.
I would like to call on the Council and particularly the member states who are reluctant to accept these detainees on their territory.

And I will tell you, dear colleagues, that the worst would be that the beautiful help aroused by the closure of Guantanamo would be taken away by what we would not have answered now, when we would have called on Europe.

because the European sector of animal feed is one of the most important sectors of agriculture, both in terms of production, since it represents half of the agricultural production in the European Union, 120 million tons, and in terms of sales, about 50 billion euros.
The European Union has 5 million breeders and 60 million homes with pets.
In the past, the European Union had to manage a number of health crises, which means that today we must be more vigilant about transparency to meet the expectations of breeders but also consumers.

The provisions provided in this report have the advantage of representing a minimal cost for the industries and a great benefit for consumers who are increasingly attentive to the quality of the products they buy.

The adoption of this report will allow to limit the risks by guaranteeing a better quality of the products, a better control, a better traceability and a greater information of the breeder and therefore, in the end, of the consumer.
Today, with the increase of international exchanges, it is imperative to strengthen all prevention mechanisms so that the food crises we have experienced in the past do not happen again.

This report conciliates the right to information while defining strictly the nutritional elements that must necessarily be listed on the labels and the right to intellectual property so important to preserve the competitiveness of our industries.

I think that manufacturers must be obliged to notify immediately the use of any new raw material that enters the composition of food for animals in order to ensure transparency and facilitate control carried out by competent authorities.
The fact of including an emergency procedure that allows to introduce a new dangerous substance in the list of prohibited substances seems to me quite essential.

In the same way, giving the breeder the possibility to question the competent national authority or the European Commission in case of doubt about an illegal allegation allows to better control the systems, both to protect the customer and to preserve the loyalty of commercial transactions.

I therefore wish to bring all my support to this excellent report, because the experience shows that a regulation on the labeling of food for animals, I end Mr. President, favoring quality, transparency, traceability and control, is the best guarantor to prevent new industrial crises in Europe.

Mr President, ladies and gentlemen, it is certainly not Europe, even less its top foreign policy representative, Ravir Solana, former NATO Secretary General, who can play the role of mediator between Israel and the Palestinians.
In addition, they are called to finance the reconstruction of the Gaza Strip, as they are doing today, for Kosovo, Lebanon or Afghanistan.
Americans and Israelis bomb, Europeans finance the reconstruction.

But it would be necessary that it be the scammers who pay
Egypt is at the center of peace talks that are based on a ceasefire with Hamas.

But the challenge has been formidable, as the new Israeli government, under the pressure of the third man, Lieberman, leader of an extreme right that is accepted there democratically, is likely to see its task singularly complicated in this negotiation.
Indeed, Netanyahu, who we present as the future Prime Minister, has always opposed a truce with Hamas.
Another difficulty is that the Palestinian Authority of Mahmoud Abbas has become, in South-Jordania, a kind of international protectorate whose legitimacy has greatly decreased among the population.

The last element to be taken into account is the expansion of the Israeli colonies, which has never ceased since 1967, making the creation of a Palestinian state in South-Jordania particularly delicate.
Today, the ball is in the Israeli camp, but do the Falcons in both camps accept this truce of God that the two parties claim without giving themselves the means?
Allow me to add a reflection on the reintegration of France into the integrated military structure of NATO, which will come into debate with the Vatanen report.
This reintegration will lead to severe obligations for France.
Indeed, we will reintegrate NATO, while the Cold War has ended since 1990.
Sarkozy seems to have forgotten the fall of the Berlin Wall and the return of Russia to the ranks of the free nations.
Should we strengthen the logic of the blocs at the time when the multipolarization and the rise in power of emerging countries, including on the military level,
In addition, France's involvement in the integrated structure will force it to strengthen its contingent in Afghanistan, while it already has 3,300 men on the ground.
with what budget will it be financed, while its defence budget will be under 2% of GDP and more than 30 regiments will be removed?
Paradoxically, we will increase our budgetary participation to integrate NATO and reduce our military presence in Africa at the same time.
The European defence, dear to President Sarkozy, will therefore be a pillar of the Atlantic alliance
It was enough to read the Lisbon Treaty and its additional protocols to convince oneself.
Whether it is in foreign policy or in common security, the European path is a dead end that will only lead to an alignment between the Americans and their allies.
It is this logic of erasure that we refuse in the name of sovereignty and national independence, which in particular relies on our autonomous nuclear dissuasion force.
Thank you, Mrs President. I congratulate our three rapporteurs for this remarkable summary they have made of the current state of our foreign policy and of the common security.

Mr. Deputy Representative, you know it better than anyone else, Europe is waiting today on the global stage to take the place assigned to it by its economic and demographic power and the richness of its democratic and humanistic values.

It is necessary to note that, despite the will of more than two-thirds of our European fellow citizens to regularly manifest, as you have said, some progress has been made, I agree with you, for ten years, but it is necessary to note that this Europe still does not exist.
If it was necessary to illustrate its erasure in the solution of the new drama in the Middle East, I would be there to demonstrate it.
There has always been a need for a European presence in Gaza to play an active role in the survival of the population and the reconstruction of the country.
and in the fight against arms smuggling, which had transformed this territory into a base for launching all-embracing rockets.
Despite the good words spoken to Sharm El-Sheikh and Jerusalem, nothing has been done about it yet.

I will once again ask a question already asked during the Lebanese crisis. When will we, Mr. High Representative, hope for the deployment of a European fleet in the Mediterranean, as we had done in the face of piracy,
We have the means
Will we ever have the will?
Well, Mr. Commissioner, Mr. President, my dear colleagues, the Parliament's decision to accept the emergency requested by the Council
The handling of this case was unanimous, both at the fishing commission last week and this morning here in Pl√©ni√®re.
We are all aware of the need for the European Union to honour the commitments made in Marrakech last November by the competent international commission, the CICTA.
It is a concrete matter to give effect to the recommendations adopted by this organization in order to stop the persistent phenomenon of overfishing of the red tuna in the
in the Atlantic, East and Mediterranean, and to face the serious dangers that are coming for the future of the species and therefore that of fishing itself.
Two of our colleagues, the Commission for fishing, Mrs Fraga and Mr Romeva Irweda, were present in Marrakech and will speak on this subject in the context of this debate.
I would like to remind you of the importance of this document, which puts into play the main dimensions of the common fishing policy, that is to say the management of
the resource, the management of the fleet, the respect of international, regional and bilateral agreements, the technical measures and above all, the control. I will come back to this later.
This is a very characteristic case, and it is a test of the credibility of this policy.
For this reason, it was not a question of the implementation of the new recovery plan without the consultation of the European Parliament.
I am therefore happy that the Commission has finally chosen the only legally and politically acceptable way to implement
of the CICTA, namely the one of a proper proposal of regulation based on Article 37 of the treaty.

The transposition of community rights taken by the Commission on the name of the European Union in the regional fishing organizations is not an insignificant operation and we insist that it be carried out under the democratic control of our institution.
I am pleased with the different measures proposed, which, although restrictive for our operators, are in line with the stakes.
The most important of these measures are certainly those concerning control, as it is true that without control, no reconstitution plan can be effective.
I thank you, Mr. Commissioner, for this proposal. I invite you to demonstrate
determination in the concrete implementation of the plan when it was approved by the Council that you put in the conclusion of a satisfactory agreement at the level of the CICTA.
Thank you Madam President, Madam Commissioner. I regret that the Council and the Commission have not yet decided to define territorial cohesion.
The French Presidency has tried it and I would like to salute this initiative
Our Parliament continues to insist that this objective be applied as soon as the Lisbon Treaty is in force and that these guidelines be specified as soon as possible.

I wish, as in the excellent report of Mr. Van Nistelrooy, that territorial cohesion becomes the legal basis guaranteeing the harmonious development of all the territories of the Union and allowing the best of the characteristics of each European region.
it is essential to better coordinate community policies in order to maximize the impact of interventions on the ground.
The territorial cohesion does not aim exclusively at regions suffering from permanent disability.
It must nevertheless be attached to the polycentric development of the European Union as a whole, taking into account the characteristics of each territory while preserving their diversity.
This new concept seems relevant to me for the taking into account of the ultra-peripheral regions in order to ensure a sustainable and balanced growth.

In this regard, I thank the rapporteur for having taken into account in his amendments the compromises but also the demands relating to the specific challenges faced by the ultra-peripheral regions in terms of accessibility and competitiveness, an essential element of territorial cohesion.
In the recent reading of the Commission's communication entitled ¬´ The RUP is an asset for Europe ¬ª, it seems to me that it wants to apply to the ultra-periphery all the
recommendations on improving governance in terms of cohesion, thus making the first illustration of the implementation of territorial cohesion.

I hope that the General States of the overseas market, which will soon begin in France, will proceed in the same way and will largely integrate the major territorial impact of European policies in favour of the RUB, whose added value is undeniable.
and undisputed
We have fun reading the conclusions of the presidency of the last council.
It looks like the victory communique of all the armies in derroute
They have the derisory until the reiterated statement that the crisis will build a stronger economy for the future or in the reaffirmation of a Lisbon strategy in the middle of the road.
Thus, as they lock themselves in their glass towers, the Eurocrats, Europhiles and Europiomans in all kinds end up no longer taking the measure of things.
Everyone knows that the eurozone was the first to enter into recession, to have known for 8 years the lowest rate in the world.
but it is also the one that faces the greatest difficulties in terms of its industrial competitiveness and the situation of employment.
Especially since it is the one that, by the general disarmament of natural defenses removed from the nations, is the least armed to react.

For the French, in any case, it is increasingly clear that there will be no salvation without France, no France without French politics, no French politics without national and popular sovereignty. Thank you Mr. President.

Thank you, Madam President. I think that the issue of distributing foodstuffs to the benefit of the poorest is quite appropriate. But I think that the Commission's proposal does not correspond to the problem.

The question of co-financing is a question I am wondering about, and I think it is more the question of liberalism that has prevailed in the evaluations of the PAC in recent years that is to be questioned.
The hunger strikes, the brutal price variations of foodstuffs are permanent indicators of the limits of the liberalization of agricultural markets.
This liberalisation has always been done at the expense of fragile populations, fragile producers and fragile territories.

I therefore plead for the policy to regain its rights, to regain control, both at the European and global level, and that the strategic field of agriculture and food for men, both from a quantitative and qualitative point of view, should not be subject to the strict market law.
Certainly, there is urgency, and the Sikorsky report responds to this urgency and I congratulate it, but I wish that in the case of the opening of the discussion on
that the priority objective is to fight structurally the hunger and poverty that we know in all member states and in the world
Rural territories are available to meet food needs with sufficient and quality production. Still, we will have to give them the human financial means to ensure this heavy responsibility.
Thank you Mr President. In this period of economic recession, it was important that the European Union continues to show its solidarity towards developing countries.
Recalling that in 2007, the European Community and the Member States have contributed together to 60% of the total development debt, making the European Union the first donor in the world.
The European Development Funds are fighting poverty while promoting economic development and democracy

I am therefore pleased that for the ACP countries, a budget of 23 billion euros was allocated for the period 2008-2013 as part of the 10th Fed, which represents practically twice the amount planned for the 9th Fed.
The Court of Accounts concluded in its report that the accounts of the 7th, 8th and 9th FED are generally loyal, legal and regular.
We can only congratulate ourselves on the record level of execution of contracts and payments of the implementation of FEDs.
However, I also see that progress must be made to strengthen the control and surveillance system, because there is always a significant level of error affecting certain transactions.
There is also a risk that is too often raised in terms of budget support and it is in my opinion better to assess these risks.
On this subject, I share the idea that budgetary support should only be granted if the country benefits from the ability to manage funds in a transparent, responsible and efficient way.

Among the priorities on which we must work in the future, I would like to mention the integration of the FED into the General Budget. I will finish with the Community, because it would strengthen the efficiency and transparency of the development aid.

To conclude, Mr President, I would also like to thank the rapporteur for his excellent report, the representatives of the Court, but also all the people of the Commission who have done an excellent job on the spot. And I obviously regret the absence of the Council and in particular of the Czech President.
The President, the Parliament and its rapporteur were forced to refuse a bad compromise. They were right to do so.
Our delegation remained faithful to the position adopted widely in the plenary session and which demanded the termination of any legal termination of work.

The representatives of the European people had cut off far beyond the partisan clashes to stop this archaism called opt-out.
We were the only ones to propose a real text of compromise that the Council of Ministers has superbly ignored, just like the Commission elsewhere.
The Council and the Commission have aligned on the position of those who are fiercely opposed to any advancement of workers' rights in Europe.
Mr. President of the Council, it is clear that you have come to your end.
The Court of Justice forces you to consider all the time you have to keep, as well as the working time, so you have not lost anything on this side.
The opt-out you want always exists in practice. The immobilist has taken it.
The deputies elected next June will have to fight to reach a harmonization of social norms.

Mr President, it is certainly not in the name of the Libyan Commission, it is probably in the name of my group. I would like to take this brief minute to give my extraordinarily positive appreciation to the report of Mrs Paganoff.

1. Independence from justice.
There are currently, in the Union, a number of countries in which the independence of justice in relation to political power or in relation to other powers is not established.

As long as we are not sure that in a certain number of countries, people who are suspected or accused of committing certain types of crimes benefit from a guarantee similar to that of other countries, it is difficult to make the principle of mutual recognition widely accepted.
This is a fundamental element and I wanted to introduce it in this debate.
Congratulations, Mrs. Pagano.
Thank you, Madam President. We cannot keep quiet about the situation in Madagascar. And we will not be the only ones to condemn this situation.

The African Union, the development community of the Austro-African Republic, the international organization of the Francophonie, the Inter-parliamentary Union, the European Union at the behest of the Commission,
In the USA, a large number of countries, including Norway and mine, have condemned the coup d'√©tat, because it is necessary to call a cat a cat, which took place in Madagascar.
So we cannot remain silent and we are asking for a return to constitutional legality.

We never ask for a return to the starting class with, if necessary, an arbitration by the Malagasy people under the guise of a consultation, under the guise of a presidential scrutiny or a referendum.
It is the responsibility of the assemblies and the political officials of Madagascar to determine the most effective form of consultation.
So what we ask with this resolution in common is to add our voice to that of the international community to clearly signify to those who have taken power in a completely non-trivial way

and in a way, under the form of a coup d'√©tat, as dressed as it is, to return to the constitutional legality of Madagascar, which is one of the guarantors of the development of this great island of the Indian Ocean.
Madam President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, I would like to thank Commissioner Dimas for his presence and for his responses to the tension he continues to bring to all these disasters
We worked together a lot when President Barroso asked me to prepare a report that he also quoted on the creation of a European Civil Protection Force.
I presented this report on May 9, 2006
When I read it again and see all the disasters that have occurred, I tell myself that there is still news.
Mrs Zanvella, obviously there is not only Greece.
All countries are concerned. And I would add that there are not only natural disasters, there are also human disasters due to humans
I think of the maritime catastrophe, the RICA and many others, industrial accidents like Chernobyl,
There are other natural disasters than fires
I think of the tsunami
We can fear a tsunami in the Mediterranean, as there was one in the early 20th century that completely destroyed the city of Messines.
Frankly, my dear colleagues, the tools we use are not at the same level as these disasters, which will multiply under the double effect of global warming and transport.
That's why I think we should be more ambitious.
I thank the Commission, Commissioner Dimas, all his teams, the General Directorate, who operate the mechanism of civil protection.
I think we should go further.
with the member countries that wish to do so. We can imagine a reinforced cooperation
If we are not 27 to make this civil protection force, let's start to be 12 or 15.
And you will see that it concerns everyone.
When I make the list of disasters, I can say that everyone is concerned. The floods that hit Germany in 2002, and even the big pandemics, and also terrorism.
So that's why I would like the Commission, with the initiative, to go further, to propose to Member States to go further
and our Parliament, the Commission for the Environment, the Commission for Defense and Security will support you in these volunteer initiatives.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, ladies and gentlemen, this summer again, the Mediterranean forest has been the prey of flames in Marseille, in South Corsica, but also in Italy, in Spain and on a larger scale in Greece.

More than 400,000 hectares of forests and fields have been destroyed by the smoke, causing considerable material disputes, irremediable damage to biodiversity, as well as dramatic losses in human lives.
Disconcerted by this repeated analysis year after year and aware of the multiplicative effect of global warming on fires,
I call for a European awareness for better coordination of efforts and a mutualization of anti-fire means of struggle.
I wish to realize a vast project of Euro-Mediterranean cooperation to fight against forest fires in the context of the Union for the Mediterranean.
I salute the existing initiatives and in particular the European system of information on forest fires, pilot project
I nevertheless demand a reform of the European Union's Solidarity Fund so that it becomes a performing tool to respond to crises and a reinforcement of the European
protection and the EuroAid program, imagined by Michel Barnier in 2006 to intervene on the territory of the 27 member countries and abroad.

I think that one of the keys to the problem of forest fires is the exchange of knowledge and good practices in terms of prevention. I would like to point out the pioneering role played by foresters in my own department
And I can of course make this example useful for Europe.

referendum in Ireland, as if it was normal to have a people vote again who expressed himself in a sovereign way and as if it was normal that an assentment to a treaty could be a currency of exchange.

ratifying a treaty is a minimum requirement of loyalty and cohesion from the moment one chooses that his country adheres to the European Union.
We wanted to give a strong signal to citizens by ratifying the treaty for the European elections of June 2009
What do you think that today the citizen thinks of the Lisbon Treaty and beyond our internal coherence and our legitimacy?
Thank you Mr President. My intervention is about the deterioration of working conditions in Europe.
Today, nearly half of the world's workers earn less than 2 dollars a day.
12.3 million people are still subject to slavery and more than 200 million children are forced to work.
In Europe, the number of poor workers is increasing day by day and the International Labour Organization denounces 160,000 deaths each year due to lack of prevention.
In this context, I would like to highlight our responsibility towards all those who are unemployed and social rights, who work in unworthy conditions,
of these millions of workers who suffer morally and physically, sometimes pushed to suicide or victims of cancer or chronic diseases due to their working conditions.
It is time to get out of the religion of working more, of the profit race, to the short-term competition
The right to decent work and the strengthening of the right to work must be at the forefront of the Union's priorities in the next ten years.
President, Mr. President of the Council, Mr. President of the Commission, a challenge for humanity, a challenge for future generations,

To lift the glove, Copenhagen must allow a global agreement, a unique agreement, as our President of the Environment Commission, Jola Inanui, said earlier. An alliance of all, industrialized countries, emerging countries, is necessary.
Today, with our debate and the elaboration of a resolution by our Parliament, we call on the European Union once again to keep its role as leader in this necessary policy of fighting climate change.
Let us remember that it is appropriate that we speak of a single voice to maintain our credibility.
And yes, we must reach a agreement in Copenhagen to limit the global average temperature to a level that does not exceed 2 degrees above pre-industrial levels.
Yes, we must sign an agreement in Copenhagen to achieve collective reductions in greenhouse gas emissions by 30% by 2020 compared to 1990.
But this will not be enough.
It is not only necessary for developed countries to significantly reduce their emissions, but also that developing countries contribute to the achievement of the objectives.

The industrialized countries must therefore provide enough financial and technical support for the developing countries to encourage them to commit themselves to reducing their greenhouse gas emissions.
Copenhagen must thus allow developing countries to evolve towards carbon-sourced models.
Also, allow me to address two points that seem necessary for our future
First, the implementation of a global climate-heating financing, based on the taxation of financial transactions.

Then, I think it is necessary to implement a fiscal adjustment to the borders of Europe, which will make importation of manufactured products without the slightest concern of environmental protection.

a contractualisation and a return to the southern countries of the carbon tax collected at the borders of Europe and which would serve to finance investments in the necessary equipment in their fight against warming.

Thank you Mr President. I would like to intervene in the same line as my intervention yesterday on the preparation of the summit of Copenhagen and following the meeting with Kofin yesterday which was not successful.
I have asked you about the responsibility we have as an industrialized country to ensure that developing countries can follow us in our efforts to fight climate change.
In Copenhagen, we can't pretend that we all have the same abilities. Otherwise, it would mean that we all leave the same place to end up with nothing.
So to convince our partners in development to join us, we will obviously have to address the question of aid, which must be granted to them and not wait for the end of the Copenhagen summit.
During the next European Council, the 27 countries will have to agree on how the European Union will help developing countries in the context of climate change.
Yesterday, as I said, the Council of Finance and the Minister of Finance failed to find a common position on this issue.
Yet we know that this question is absolutely central.
The European Commission has already made proposals. I absolutely hope that we will take the lead to lead our partners towards a necessary global solidarity to overcome this problem of climate change.
We have seen the efforts of the Swedish President to achieve an ambitious agreement in Copenhagen, despite the strong wind of pessimism that blows on these future negotiations.
For my part, I think that it is not to prove realism to admit at this stage that the summit of Copenhagen is dead or that it will not lead to a conclusive agreement to be ratified by all parties.
Let's not give in to pessimism too quickly.
I plead that at this stage, we do not see our ambitions going down, neither in terms of objectives nor in terms of deadlines.
We must continue to believe in a complete, ambitious and compelling global political agreement, which opens the way to the conclusion of a legal treaty as soon as possible,
It is really too early to mention the deadline for the COP 16 of December 2010.
We must now translate our rhetoric into real political will
We must clarify our commitment in terms of financial and aid to the developing countries, especially in terms of technological transfers.
At this stage, a total and collective commitment of the European Union is essential.
I note on paper the recent but exemplary rise given by Brazil, South Korea, Indonesia, Norway in particular, which have set their ambitions to reduce their polluting emissions.

If we can understand the flexibility demanded by the United States, which is only beginning to take into account the climate issue, we will still have to achieve encrypted commitments that are restrictive and ambitious in the short, medium and long term from other major polluters such as the United States and China.
In the absence of this, we are running to the climate, political and moral disasters.
Madame President, we all know and we have all said the importance of the negotiations in Copenhagen, but if we all hope for an agreement, we cannot accept an agreement at any cost.
If the conditions for an ambitious agreement are not met, I very clearly wish that the European Union is able to say no and refuse to sign an agreement with the RAB.
The European populations that we represent here are waiting for an agreement that will allow us to fight effectively against all the climate change that we see happening around us every day.

They will not be content with the effects of announcements, declarations of non-digital intentions, non-contraining objectives on which it will be possible to wash one's feet once the media projector is off.

In Copenhagen, states must commit. The European Union, the only continent that has seen its CO2 emissions decrease since 1990, the only continent to foresee precise, restrictive and ambitious commitments for the future, can only assume the burden of effort.

This is why, if other emerging industrialized countries do not want to take their share of the burden, we will have to take all the consequences by setting up a tax on our borders protecting our industry from competition, from those who would decide not to participate in a global agreement.
We Europeans ask our industrialists a little more every day.
I want to prove it with the climate package signed under French presidency

I want to prove the national initiatives that, like the carbon tax, which was earlier praised by Mr. Parniot and I congratulate him, these national initiatives push for the establishment of an ecological tax.

A sector such as transport, which is among the major CO2 emitters, even if some modes of transport such as aviation emit less greenhouse gas, contributes more and more to the fight against climate change.
Yet this is a sector that has suffered greatly the counter-attack of the crisis

If, as I wish, maritime and air transports are included in the negotiations in Copenhagen, then let us ensure that what will be demanded of the European industries will also be demanded of those of other industrialized countries.
In Copenhagen, the global public opinion will have its eyes on its ruling class.
Madam President, my dear colleagues, the Copenhagen summit is a historic opportunity to change the course of the planet.
We must make decisions that are even more restrictive than those in Kyoto.
We also have to call on our leaders to create an international organization such as the OMC, in charge of regulating the issues of climate change and the environment, to create a foundation
to adapt to climate change in addition, of course, to public development assistance, to create a maritime and air carbon tax, as we must also do on financial transactions.
We can see the pressing need for global environmental regulation, such as the one for Internet financial markets.
We have the opportunity to open this path of history through the environment
Let's do it, in the image of our highest human aspirations, without which we will appear as responsible people, without any grip on the reality of things. Thank you.

Thank you Madam President, Mr. President of the Council, Mr. President of the Commission, my dear colleagues. Less than two weeks after the Copenhagen conference, the concerns are growing regarding the success of negotiations on climate change
Some, by the way, already say that it will be a failure.
of great world power still reshaping to prove the entire ambition that the climate emergency imposes on us.

we will not be able to resolutely bring the decision to hand, otherwise it will be too late. Thank you Mr. President, Mrs. Minister, dear colleagues. The importance of the issue of climate change is no longer to be proven.
These short, medium or long-term impacts are undeniable, even if today the results of the GESC in a certain national newspaper are the only one and certainly strengthen the skeptics' positions.
The Copenhagen summit appeared to the world as a unique opportunity for world leaders to testify, to act and to correct the effects of this process that is climate change.

The European Union was at the forefront of this debate, not only thanks to the bold legislation that is ours in terms of limiting the impact of our activities on the climate, but also because Europe represents a union of countries that can really make a difference.
Certainly, the conference in Copenhagen can only leave a taste for dissatisfaction. But I refuse to talk about failure.
The world has agreed on the issue of a limitation of the increase of the temperature of 2 degrees and this even for a country of the most reluctant like China.
Brazil has just promulgated a law that aims to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by nearly 39% by 2020, in accordance with its commitments.
Many others have also shown great ambitions regarding the objectives of reducing greenhouse gas emissions
I think of Japan and Norway.
In addition, we must also highlight this very positive point that was the consensus made concerning the urgency of a mechanism for reducing emissions due to deforestation.
A specific and unanimous text was obtained on the implementation of the DIRED-PLUS mechanism to reduce deforestation and thus allow the natural storage of CO2.
Far from a straining agreement, but clearly within the lines of a political agreement, the outcome of Copenhagen must lead us to question the reasons for such a disappointment.
I went to the Copenhagen conference as many of my colleagues, with this desire to participate, to help, to see a negotiating Europe, a leader Europe,
My disappointment was great because Europe clearly did not have the place it deserved in the negotiations, especially when it comes to the European Parliament.
To impose oneself, Europe must show itself stronger on the subject
and the meeting of our ministers on the environment in Seville has not ended. And our officials have shown themselves uncertain, hesitant, and we remain divided on our objectives.
I hope that Mrs. Edegarde, strong of her proposals and her commitments, will be able to bring the ambitions of the European Union to the level of the Commission of the Environment.
Dear colleagues, to avoid caricatures, I would like to mention a few objective elements concerning Tunisia, a partner country of the European Union.

The social situation has evolved very favourably, with a spectacular increase in the average income per capita and now the vast majority of Tunisians are among the criteria defining the belonging to the middle class.

More than 90% of Tunisians benefit from social coverage and more than a quarter of the budget of Tunisia is dedicated to education, so this country is among the very first to have reached the objectives of the millennium in primary education.

many countries could be inspired by such results.
