It is a PME of more than 10 employees, of more than 1 million euros of turnover,
Whatever the member state, it represents a very large majority of companies.
Certainly, they may be local and not present on the community market. But it is no less important that the need to introduce accounting rules will not be abolished for them
They will have to face these accounting rules whenever they want to negotiate with a bank, with partners or with tax, economic and social institutions.
At this point, accounting rules will be imposed on them and they will have to pay perhaps more than for regular accounting to be able to meet criteria that they will not necessarily master.
I do not see any progress in what the accounting obligation then imposes outside of any common framework in the European Union.
This is not just a problem of competition, it is simply a question of economic integration and of community rights and of equal treatment for all the companies of the European Union.
That being said, of course simplifying accounting obligations for SMEs is a necessity.
Three initiatives are going in this direction. The proposal we are talking about today, the International Referential
whether it is the revision of the 4th and 7th accounting directives for which the European Commission should soon make proposals.
These proposals were promised to us for 2010, it seems that they will be extended, but I do not believe that this extension of the deadline is a sufficient reason for this
to rush and do half the work. Because these three proposals, if they share the same objective, may not have the same articulation. And it seems to me that it would be better, Mr. Commissioner,

and clearer for companies to provide them with a unique and global response that will allow them to reconcile the objective of simplification of the obligations desired by all and the reality of the lives of small companies that need it.
The current problem is that the European Commission is dragging forward a revision of its directives and that this is harmful to our thinking.

I therefore call on the European Commission to accelerate dialogue on the issue of the exemption that divides today both institutions and European economic environments and to conduct an impact study.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner and my dear colleagues, As my colleague Elisabeth Morin-Chartier and my other colleagues have indicated, on February 27 and 28, the violent Sintia storm hit several French regions, killing 53 people and causing enormous material damage.
The storm was of a rare intensity. It caused devastating floods on the French coast.
After Mad√®re, Europe is once again concerned.
Brittany, the region of my colleague and friend Alain Kadek, has been severely affected
Three French departments have been declared in a state of natural disaster. Brittany, Port-au-Charentes and the Loire countries.
Faced with these disasters, the European Union must show its reactivity and express its solidarity.
Not only through words and a resolution, but also and above all through financial aid that we can support the victims of these disasters.
I invite my colleague Christophe B√©chut to join me in my approach. The European Commission has quickly unblocked the Union's Solidarity Fund to help the distressed regions to deal with the damage.
This catastrophe demonstrates the relevance of Michel Barnier's proposal to create a European Civil Intervention Force.

Europeans must act together because the disasters are multiplying and are affecting our European territories and in particular our most isolated and vulnerable regions, such as the islands in the Indian Ocean and the Caribbean.

Thank you, Madam President. I would also like to congratulate our reporter J√∂rg Leichtfried for his text and his spirit of cooperation in this case. I support in particular what concerns his proposals on the financing of air safety, since we are talking here about air safety and not air safety.

It has been many years since our Commission has fought to accept the principle that the strictest measures in terms of safety must be at the charge of Member States and I fully support our rapporteur on this point.
Indeed, safety concerns not only travelers but all citizens. It is the responsibility of the states to take measures to fight terrorism.
It is therefore not justified that it is the air passengers who are responsible for financing the safety measures in airports and on board aircraft.
And even more so because in transport modes such as rail and maritime, states finance, in some cases, partially or totally, safety measures.
I think we should remain firm with the Council and defend until the end the amendment 32 of the report adopted by our Transport Commission.
I have another point to quickly address

If I support the progress in non-discrimination and transparency that the text will bring, I do not believe that the purpose of this directive is to set up a unique and identical European system of security guarantees.
By obliging the public to respect the common rules, we must allow member states to keep their current system of revocation of the benefits

In states such as Spain, Italy or France, the benefits are voted by the Parliament. In this case, it must be the authority to resort to the laws that must act as an authority of independent supervision,
and it is the object of amendment 40 that I hope many of you will support when we vote for it.
Thank you Mr President, Mr Commissioner. The report I present to the Parliament tries to explain that in the fight against climate change, agriculture has a place and a role to play.
Nature reminds us this week that, and volcanoes in particular, can have a major impact on human activities and on the climate.
But it still requires that men, and Europe in particular, take on their responsibilities to fight against what is called climate warming.
My report tries to show that agriculture can both continue to reduce its carbon emissions, to reduce its fossil energy consumption and above all to have another
to actively participate in the fixation of carbon to fight globally for less carbon waste and more carbon fixed and sequestered.
This report tries to show that in agriculture we should go from a compartmentalized approach, which consists of opening a directive every time we have a problem,
on soil, on water, on pesticides, what else do I know, and to try to address the agricultural issue with the ambition to treat it globally, systematically.

And in this approach, we must be able to find some leads to ensure that agriculture, as I said earlier, not only reduces its energy consumption, but at the same time participates in a very active way in the fixation of carbon.
This is in particular the role linked to photosynthesis, biomass and then above all, what is important to me, also linked to the soil, to this capacity that European soils have to fix organic carbon.

I think that this track that I am opening in this report, and that I hope will be followed during the vote that will take place in Pellini√®res in Bruxelles, this track must allow European agriculture to enter a phase of sustainability, to ensure a

ecological transition to this agriculture, which would put it ahead on a certain number of other continents or other agriculture to ensure that it is able to be performing economically, performing ecologically and I also think from that moment on performing socially.

This report deals with a particular issue, the fight against climate change and agriculture, but it has the pretension, I hope, to open other perspectives to feed the debate that will be held on the future of agriculture after 2013.
I will address the Commission, I will address the different Ministers when I have the opportunity
I think we need to take a turn.
This 2013 pact must be ambitious.
It must rely on objectives that allow citizens to understand why we need a common agricultural policy.
We need a common agricultural policy because Europe's agriculture must ensure both food security and also engage in the road to sustainability
This is what I propose in this report and I hope that the Parliament will follow me.

Thank you Mr President. I would like to underline that the precautionary principle implemented by most European governments by closing their airspace in a targeted and provisional way was a wise and prudent decision.

The safety of our fellow citizens must be prioritized over any other consideration. And in these conditions, the attitude of some airlines that demand the total and immediate reopening of the airspace on both one or two test flights appears to be at least indecent.
I think that Mr. H√©nin spoke earlier about the complementarity of transport modes, particularly with the train. I will take this opportunity to say how much I regret that the air traffic
had been accentuated in some countries like France by the disorganization of rail transport due to strikes in these irresponsible and incomprehensible circumstances.
To return to our subject, I would like to congratulate the Commission's decision to authorize the public aid to the airlines affected by the disturbances in progress
This is a reasonable decision in a context already marked by the crisis, but these aids must be of exceptional character.
I wish that among the criteria for the ROC 3, the exemplarity of which companies have proven in the compensation given to their clients victims of cancellation of flight.
Indeed, it is not acceptable that some companies abuse the clause of major force in order to escape their obligation to indemnify passengers issued from Regulation 261-2004.
Travelers are victims of the current situation and if no alternative solution is proposed to them, they must not in addition bear the financial cost.
In addition, travel agencies are exempted from the obligation to refund non-used flights to travelers
And this is not normal either.

Companies, like travel agencies, have insurance that covers them in exceptional cases, like the one we have been experiencing for a few days, and it is therefore necessary to ensure that travelers are well indemnized of the flights that have been cancelled.
Thank you Mr. President. Trouble, chaos, paralysis, cacophony, disaster, disaster, the words are not missing in the press to evoke the closure of European airspace and its consequences.
I will not dwell on what has already been said, especially when we cry about the colossal financial impact, abyssal, one might say, of this crisis in direct or indirect terms.

And if I am pleased with the possibility of considering the opportunity of exceptional public aid to the air sector, already strongly approved since September 2011, I am no less perplexed about the European management of events.

1. Knowing that 750,000 European passengers have been deported, of which a good part are still stuck in the four corners of the world, knowing that economic losses are exponential with the passing time, how do you explain that it was necessary
not one, two, three or four but five days for the ministers of European transport to meet by teleconference to coordinate their actions and decide on the creation of differentiated traffic zones.
2. No one is against the necessity of applying the precautionary principle in absolute priority. But today, while traffic is gradually reauthorized in
and while the volcano is still active, we have the right to ask ourselves what are the additional security guarantees for passengers that we could have provided earlier, more quickly.

3. An evolutionary action model has been developed. The evolution of the weather and the activity of the volcano can change from hour to hour. It will continue to proceed with the updated evaluation of the security of the corridors.
Should these flight tests be carried out by civil aviation and air companies?

Finally, if it lasts, worsens or reproduces, which is likely, the model of management set up will have to provide greater coordination of member states and special operational procedures based on real data,

the coordination of other means of transport in exceptional circumstances, but also taking into account the necessary coordination of the aid to the repatriation of tens of thousands of blocked passengers who also have the right to information and assistance.
However, so far, only isolated and national initiatives have been taken.
Thank you, Madam President. I would like to thank our colleague Mendez de Vigo, who has done a remarkable job in conditions that are sometimes exciting and always exciting.
The debates within the Commission have lasted a long time. They have been at the height of the issue and at the height of the intensity of interest that the parties obviously put
in the major subject concerning our first chief, the composition of our assembly and the designations of the members of our assembly.
Once again, the reporter was able to gather different opinions and contributions and synthesize, I would say, in an extremely balanced text, the opinions and opinions.
I wanted to thank them.

I believe that the recommendations of these two reports, both those concerning the CIG's call and those concerning the transitory measures for the composition of our Assembly, are a sign of realism, pragmatism, efficiency,
I think that's what, on other subjects, the fellow citizens expect from Europe.
Thank you Mr President, Mr Dali, Mr Commissioner. It is with great strength that this report project, as presented at the moment by Mr Peterle, takes up the lines
She is the Director of the European Commission and she is also inspired by the resolution of the European Parliament on April 10, 2008 on the fight against cancer in our European Union.

Allow me to support the objectives of the European partnership, considered by the European Commission, to fight cancer more effectively, whether it is the importance of early screening prevention, the development of a new cancer prevention model and, above all, the reduction of inequalities within Member States.
I share the concerns and concerns expressed within the European Commission's communication and the report project.
I would like to thank the work done by Mr. Peterl√©, rapporteur, in the context of the writing of this report, and the proposals for compromise proposed to take up the different amendments.

As a fictional reporter for the Socialist and Democratic group, I would like to focus on the following questions. First of all, the increase in annual deaths due to cancer caused by exposure to cancerous agents at work, but also the importance of better access to

information on drugs for patients with cancer, but also the implementation of the REACH regulation and the regular update of very worrying substances that take up cancerous substances, support for initiatives aimed at preventing the import of goods

containing chemical substances and to strengthen the control of chemical substances within the European Union. And finally, the development of guidelines for a common definition of disability, including people suffering from chronic diseases or cancer.
These are the questions we have asked, while also bringing our support to this report.
Yes, thank you, Madam President. The oil drilling leak in the Mexican Bay is a real ecological and economic disaster.
it would appear that irregularities would have been observed in the 3rd act by the Ministry of the Interior of the United States of Forest Permits.
It would be an unforgivable lightness whose consequences are incalculable and do not concern only the United States of America.

When we know that in the world hundreds of offshore drilling authorizations are granted by the States, if these authorizations are granted with the same lightness, it would pose a real serious problem to the whole world.
elected from ultra-peripheral European regions and PTOMs, composed entirely of islands, nearly entirely of islands, nearly 130.
In total, in the three continents, I must say here my great concern for our islands vis-√†-vis oil exploitation projects in the sea.
This is why it is imperative that the European Union, in order to set an example, review with the utmost rigor the security and prevention measures on its own offshore oil platforms.
Moreover, the accidental or operational oil spills in the sea, not necessarily due to Europe, are evaluated at several tens of thousands of tons each year.

Would it not be appropriate for the European Union to take initiatives so that the sea platforms now belong to an unquestioned scientific international authority that would be appropriate to be implemented in the form of an international authority?
After Copenhagen and in preparation for Cancun, the European Union would be honored to initiate a real global governance for the research, protection and exploitation of marine resources.

In the continuity of the process in Barcelona, the union for the Mediterranean is a chance for the development of our relations with the countries of the East and the South of the Mediterranean basin.
And as the excellent report of Vincent P√©ion emphasizes, we cannot neglect the potential of this region, nor the dangers it bears.
However, having the lucidity to recognize it, since the bombing of Gaza and with the pursuit of the colonization of Palestinian territories, the Union for the Mediterranean is in a deadlock.
the political sphere is blocked.
We are not even sure that the summit scheduled for next June in Barcelona will take place
I wouldn't be surprised if we learned in the coming hours or days that it is a day so special.
We must not give up. But the European Union must take on these responsibilities in search of a political solution.
We cannot leave the monopoly of the political management of the crisis of this region, which is ours, to the United States by contenting us to contribute to its development.
Development and stability of the Mediterranean condition our security and growth. For this reason, the Union for the Mediterranean remains the best instrument at our disposal.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, this is an extremely important issue concerning consumer protection.
A recent survey shows that the food security situation has deteriorated for 10 years in the eyes of Europeans. And 1 out of 3 consumers are wary of the quality of the products.
So updating, simplifying, clarifying the guidelines of food standards in the European Union is an obligation for better consumer protection.
Allow me to address two points.
Regarding the color code, we are in favor of this color code if it is accompanied by a reference to the nutritional value expressed in percentage.
And then I am opposed to an obligatory nutritional declaration for wines and spiritual drinks.
We wish to develop a specific regulation for wine and spiritual drinks in the next three years instead of the five years proposed by the European Commission
This is what I would like to say, Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner.
Mr President, Mrs. High Representative, this attack of civilian ships by the Israeli commandos obviously requires an impartial and credible investigation.
But what credit could we give to a commission that would be both judge and party?
This attack occurred in international waters, it concerns the international community, it is particularly interested in Europe, the Mediterranean coastline.
Europe should be heard more and be more involved in the search for a political solution based on two states, each with Jerusalem as its capital.

Europe is making considerable financial efforts to contribute to the development of Palestinian territories, but unfortunately it is too absent from the political process that should lead to the creation of this Palestinian state.
The good financial and budgetary will that we demonstrate is not enough
We must also express a political will and take the means to make us heard.
The brutal attack of the Mavi Marmara by the Israeli army aroused emotions and condemnation.
emotions in front of the 9 victims of the assault of civilians, condemnation because this misguidance in international zones constitutes a violation of international law.
This is why the government of Israel is penalizing its people because in the end we see, with the strengthening of the extremes, the ultimate goal of security in the region is a little further away.
Yes, more than ever, the government of Israel must renounce the policy of force.
I would like to note that the strong media coverage of the Marmara Navy fleet, orchestrated since Turkey, casts doubt on the exclusively humanitarian purpose of this operation.
An investigation seems essential to shed light on the assault, but also on the preparations that preceded this expedition.
I hope that the government of Israel accepts that this investigation includes a substantial international participation to finally find the paths of justice in this region.
Madam President, Madam High Representative, I congratulate you on the new dynamic induced by the launch of the Partnership for Modernization and its pragmatism.
This new partnership, if only it were useful, would at least have the merit of highlighting how much Russia is an essential geopolitical partner for the European Union.
I also congratulate myself on the positive comments on cooperation with Russia in crisis management.
A few remarks, however.

While the demands of the Union are always put forward, the interests or positions of its partner seem systematically undervalued or denied, whether it is the field of energy or the way in which it can analyze the Oriental partnership and the Atlantic aspirations of its closest neighbors.
I also note that the firmness that most Member States and the Union show in their speeches, the virulence of the condemnations of the violations of human rights, seems reserved only for Russia.

The words are more policed, the diplomacy more veiled, as if it were China, for example, of these systematic violations of the rule of law, if only on the subject of the Laoga√Ø, this global factory, in regard to the minimum social requirements of the European Union, when our French and European workers are unemployed.

Allow me to remind you of the adage of Augustus, Father Augustus, towards the heights through narrow paths, because this is how I consider the efforts of Russia today, delivered from the Marxist criminal poison that for decades will have stained and locked this country.
The current Russian Confederation will have been able to raise the head of a whole nation despite the difficulties and important tasks that remain to be done.

So, a little modesty, gentlemen Europeans, especially when the super-European state does not reach any of its beautiful objectives despite increasingly expensive means and the progressive domination of the states of Western Europe and Central and Eastern Europe.
I cannot help but recall that this assembly had more indulgences towards the Soviet Union than towards Russia.

They are often the same who yesterday fought for the unilateral disarmament of the West and for the participation in the House of Commons of Mr Gorbachev, who today prove the most virtuous indignation and the greatest shame towards the Russian Union.

I must inform you about this if you are not yet, of new historical facts that will appear due to the progressive translation of Soviet secret archives that a brave Mr. Pavel Stroilov will have been able to procure. Archives that have already given and will still give a lot of

a unpleasant surprise to the caciques of the unique thinking regarding the reality of the end of the Cold War, which was really Mr Gorbachev, and the forfeiture of the European powers of today, which then wanted with enthusiasm to make possible some Soviet projects.
at the risk of repeating myself, Russia is an essential and strategic partner for the European states and our relations must be strengthened to the benefit of all parties
This country is much closer to us in terms of culture, civilization, history, geography, mutual interest or common risk than some states that you are now ready to make join the European Union.
As the President of the Council, we often say that necessity is law.
in the face of the crisis of unevidence, what I call a necessity that has become inevitable, that of innovating, of being creative.

In this regard, I rejoice in the Council's decision, a step that I hope will be a giant step towards a true economic governance, because, let us not be mistaken, the simple coordination of economic policies will remain insufficient.
Can we achieve a real budget federation, not forced by the circumstances, but because we would have decided it ourselves?
Let's go back to the decision of the Council, which still pleases me.
the strengthening of the preventive part of the growth stability pact is an excellent thing, but there is no real vegetarian discipline without sanctions for those who are disturbed.
They have been reinforced, but not yet specified. It is a regret.

Otherwise, I will tell you my satisfaction, among other things, in relation to the orientations of these ideas, such as the famous board of evaluation of competitiveness, because that is what it is about, renewing with competitiveness and sustainable growth for all.
It still owes the project of the installation of a tax, the acceptance of a taxation of financial transactions, the acceleration of the reform of financial regulations.
Mr. President of the Council, all these decisions and orientations seemed a few months ago, or even a few weeks ago, unrealistic, illusory, or even really hypothetical.
You are right, it is true, it is a change of culture deep at the level of the policy of the little European steps.
But that said, it is now obligatory that in October, the States implement these guidelines very concretely.

It will now depend on the Council whether the step taken is a historic step or simply a stale wish, which we will all bitterly regret, and in particular a majority of citizens, to suffer on a daily basis. Thank you.

Mr. President, we have already discussed this at the Conference of Presidents. Many groups are divided on this Gallo report and, visibly, the Parliament, all groups still need to discuss because there are some contradictory points that the groups have not been able to resolve.
So that's why we asked to postpone the debate and the vote of the Gallo report, that is to say in September, September 2, when we will have to see the conference of the presidents.
So it's a very simple thing.
Since the fruit is not ripe, let it ripen to ripen and let's discuss in September.

Thank you, Madam President. I admit that it is difficult to follow my colleagues who so much like to show their muscles and to show that they are the monopoly of our legitimacy in the face of other institutions of the Union.
Unfortunately, their posture is often derisive.
But when the members of this House, by force of work and conviction, assert an argumentative position,
we defend what looks like a European general interest in the face of tense states, the situation changes completely.
In this debate on European supervision, the Parliament has played this role.
On the subject of the European Committee on Systemic Risk, which I am the fictional reporter of my group, I defended as the reporter Mrs Goulard an ambitious line.
I took mechanisms that ensured a certain efficiency and I insisted on the preeminence of the ECB.
Why?
because the ECB is the only community institution in this group and because it has proven to be serious.
By Christian charity, I would like to bury the names of all the institutions and all these great figures who suddenly disappeared during the storm,
we can be happy to have had at least one captain on board, at the highest level of the crisis.
I would therefore be reassured to see tomorrow the macro-prudential surveillance adduced to a strong community institution, while the micro-prudential surveillance will necessarily remain fragmented.
We have forgotten that the European Committee on Systemic Risk must get to work as soon as possible
The future will show if the necessary arrangements will be made, but it is essential to start on healthy bases, because systemic risks affect the entire European and global banking sector.
Thank you Mr. President. The final agreement on the refund of the industrial emissions directives is more than acceptable and I salute the compromise work that has been carried out.

This final package takes up the key points of the position that I defended with several of my colleagues within the Environment Commission and which aimed to make this text an ambitious but realistic legislation.
First, the maintenance of a certain flexibility for companies and competent authorities for the approval of the derogations.
Then, I would like to salute the new version of the ESN, so controversial and which, in the future, limited to certain sectors, seems much more achievable.

It is also important to highlight that the agreement found allows for better articulation with the ETS directive and definitely withdraws from the text of the new directive the unimportant idea of the creation of a quota market SO2 and NOx.
However, there are a few drawbacks to not forget, and more particularly the ground-related provisions.
The SOL directive is still in the works, this important issue will unfortunately be addressed only by Member States who have their own legislation.
Tomorrow, Parliament will have to adopt the elements of the agreement found at the end of the Trilogues.

A huge amount of work has been provided in order to avoid the return of this text in conciliation, a text that I must remind you of its crucial importance both for the industry and for European environmental policy.
Madam President, every day brings its information that shows us the extent of the ecological disaster caused in the Gulf of Mexico with the rupture of the offshore platform.
But let's not forget that other disasters of this kind have taken place elsewhere.
I am thinking in particular of what is happening today in Nigeria,
That is why, in addition to the moratorium for new drilling, I think there is a need to promote stricter rules for the management of platforms, not only European rules but also international rules.
for the European Union. I think it is necessary that it is provided in a preventive way for the fight against this disaster and I think it is obvious
We also want all of this to plead, as Mrs Damanaki said, for a firm and resolute choice in favour of clean and renewable energies
and the European Union should set an example in this regard.

Mr President, Mr Commissioner, reopening negotiations with Mercosur while the European Union is preparing to redefine its agricultural policy reveals a dangerous lack of coherence from the Commission.
Europe already imports 500,000 tons of beef.
A new opening of our market will be made to the comfort of farmers in the European unfavorable areas without guarantee of respect for health and social standards.
We cannot accept it.
Europe buys 38 million tons of soy and feed the cattle.
These imports from Brazil and Argentina monopolize more than 19 million hectares.
They are concentrated in the hands of three companies. Cargill, ADM, Bunch.
Between 2001 and 2004, soja destroyed more than 1.2 million hectares of tropical and equatorial forests.
This was one of the first reasons for the increase in greenhouse gas emissions and the disappearance of biodiversity.
The European Parliament has decided to produce a report on the reconquest of the autonomy of plant proteins for the feeding of cattle.
A respectful agriculture of the environment and the fight against climate change dictates this choice.
These efforts will be cut to nothing by this bilateral agreement
Once again, the European Commission is trying to get its farmers and agriculture to get random counterparts for service companies.
These concessions will be of no use to the peasant families of Mercosur, but to the interests of agro-industrial groups.
To be sure, you just need to read the report of the group Tyson, an American company, a heavyweight in the international meat market,
which announces having invested in Brazil for, I quote, and this is in its report, to use this country as an export platform for Europe.
Other companies, such as the company Doux, had already anticipated this approach by buying back the Brazilian group Frango Sul in 1998.
Many cattle breeders, particularly in Brittany, had to pay for this operation.
Europe, without pursuing its policy of relocation by amplifying its attacks,
against the peasants. We must stop
Yes, Mr President, many colleagues are worried about the consequences on European agriculture that could have the reopening of negotiations of an agreement of association with Mercosur.
My group and myself share these concerns.

As a member of a ultra-peripheral region, I have experience in agreements on bananas. It is therefore to be feared that an agreement with Mercosur will not be difficult to deal with in many European agricultural sectors.
This is why an impact study is absolutely necessary.

It is also to be feared that this agreement will turn the agriculture of the Mercosur a little too much towards a productive agriculture, at the expense of small exploitations that exist in these countries.

A balance must therefore be found so that this agreement does not transform the Latin American and European continents into superpowers essentially anchored on the dogma of mercantilism. Thank you Mr President.
Thank you Mr President. I would just like to say that we may not have done our job well today.
If we let free trade agreements enter the territory of Europe, products that do not respect our social norms, nor our environmental norms, the reform of the Pact will be useless.
In a very clear way, we cannot remain in hypocrisy, where on the one hand we impose environmental constraints on sanitary traceability and safety,
to our farmers, because we must protect consumers and on the other hand, leave products that can enter freely on our continent without respecting its
The question that is asked behind the negotiation with Mercosur is this one.

and the way things were initiated, whatever we are told about the fact that the Parliament was very well informed and that things went in the greatest transparency and clarity, does not lead us to bring a positive appreciation on a negotiation that is registered while in parallel the negotiations continue at the OMC,
In the name of consistency, of the defense of consumers and of the defense of our farmers, I do not believe that we should continue in this way.

Thank you Madam President. I would also like to salute the work done by reporter Jos√© Bov√©, salute the Commissioner and the intervention of Mr. Dess who preceded me on the objectives of this report.

I think it is very important to keep in mind that in the debate we have, we have to solve a problem related to the volatility of agricultural prices and especially related to the fact that when prices
they are quickly distributed, but when prices drop in production, there is no repercussion for consumers.
So there is a problem of organization of the chain, there is a problem of distribution of what is called the added value within the chain,

And I think that the report of Jos√© Bov√© offers on several points perspectives that must be put forward, and here I really address the Commission, to try to get out of this spiral fundamentally negative.
The first, of course, is the organization of the chain and the strength relationship within the chain.
What are the proposals we make so that producers can gather, organize and have more weight in the chain to negotiate?
This is the question you have raised, Mr. Interprofessionals Commissioner, but it is also a question on the contractual basis that will be put in place.
And I plead, and I know in the report, that this contractual base is a European framework.
We can't let each country solve this problem.
There has to be a European framework.
It must be flexible, but it must exist.
This is an indissociable proposition for me.
Secondly, of course, the question of price transparency
And I am in favour of the establishment of this observatory, which is absolutely necessary, so that we can inform consumers of the evolution of prices.
So I support the proposals that have been made and I hope, as Mr. Dess said, that there will be a majority to follow.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, Today I would like to salute this debate that once again marks the need for the Union to appreciate and to enhance its regional diversity.
In these negotiations of the new framework programs 2014-2020, it seems important to me to highlight the arrangements that specific regions must benefit from.
The questions of continuity and territorial cohesion must be at the heart of our concerns.
But the development of mountainous territories, insulated or lowly populated, requires more than a set of erogatory measures.
We need a horizontal approach
we must put in place the instruments capable of making all areas of community action coexist in synergy in order to strengthen their added value.

Moreover, as a representative of the ultra-peripheral regions, I am eagerly awaiting the new strategy of the Union for the RUPES that the Commission's services have promised us for the beginning of 2011.
Thank you, Madam President, Mr. Commissioner, my dear colleagues. First of all, I would like to address the position of my colleague regarding the absence of the Council at this Parliament meeting.
I find this a bit disheartening from the Council, I also want to say that.
So, as the next summit of October 6 approaches, China and the European Union must absolutely and resolutely try to move forward together on the issue of climate change.
Last year, at the same time, we were already busy in this same hemicycle, to urge Europe to implement everything to reach an ambitious and restrictive agreement in Copenhagen
we have seen that the results were not up to our expectations and ambitions.
So the worries a year later are the same, even more vivid.

So, in order to be able to force or convince our partners, we must show that our determination is absolutely intact. For example, we must show that we are giving the means to honour our commitments to the countries of the South.
For this, the implementation of innovative financing becomes a necessary evidence.
For example, the installation of a carbon tax on our borders is not to be excluded

It would act as an incentive mechanism for countries that are not far from their commitment to the climate and much more than a threat in the end. And a way to protect our jobs and our companies, especially to better address the post-crisis.

Thank you, Madam President. For me, the need to revalorize family leave is not to be proven. To raise the minimum threshold of maternity leave is an advance, a benefit, and we must not be totally demagogic by comparing the economic impact to the qualitative benefits that are hardly quantifiable.

But the problem is essentially of two orders. 1. The economic context is true, but not enough to leave in the hands of millions of families for decades. 2. The legal gaps of the report, because the text contains in its essence several types of family holidays whose legal bases are not conciliable.
Let's take the maternity and paternity leave, which are in the text.
I personally appreciate as a mother adopting, and for all those I embody, the will to give equal rights to those of biological mothers.
I am in fact the small additional package that Mrs Morin mentioned in her report on Estrella.

If the objective is to strengthen the health and rights of all women in the labour market, the women who adopt, who have become mothers in the same way as others, have the same rights and the same protection at work.
They are mothers like any other, who adopt a child of more or less than 12 months, no discrimination please, as it is stated in the text.
Regarding the adoption, I regret that the text was so little in depth.
It was not even fed by the impact study of Rembolle.
All this is not well accomplished, which is clearly a weak point.

Nevertheless, despite these drawbacks, I will support Mrs. Estrella's report because beyond economic considerations, there are men and women who must not only better assume their parenting in a society of

more and more demissionaries in the education of these young people, but also because it is our duty to ensure that no one is to choose to sacrifice his children for his work or to sacrifice his work for his children.
Finally, we are not sitting in the Council but in Parliament. If we, the direct elected, are not ambitious, tell me who will be?
Madam President, Mr. Commissioner, Mr. President of the Council, I would like to intervene and not return to the debate as it has been going on so far.

We discussed a budget for 2011 with the constraints that we know, that is to say, that of a deep crisis that crosses Europe with public deficits at the national level, which can lead to two hypotheses.
These national public difficulties constrain the European difficulties, where these national difficulties must give a new orientation and a new breath to the scale of Europe.
That's the question.
And I ask you, Mr. Commissioner, to think about it, when we talk about a budget revision, when we start talking about the budget prospects for the year after 2013,
to remain totally impregnated by the context of the crisis. Except to tell me, and to tell all citizens of Europe, that Europe will stay for a long time in the crisis.
Our whole problem is indeed to manage the crisis and to reduce our deficits and our income, but it is also to prepare the outcome of the crisis.
And this is where the question arises.

We cannot get out of the crisis, and it was said by Joseph Dehaut immediately, that if the European budget, because it is European, is able to give us the means to find what we lack today, growth, job creation, innovation, research,

That is the challenge. And it is at this point that we must discuss the budget and not do as we often do, constantly integrating the issue of crisis, the issue of difficulties. And here the Council is excellent.

I noted that in Deauville, Angela Merkel and Nicolas Sarkozy even announced in advance a reform of the treaties, without even having discussed with Mr. Van Rompuy about anything, to sanction all states that would not respect tomorrow a budgetary discipline.
This is where we are today at the Council, while the Parliament only asks one thing, and in particular the Commission, to try to pull the European project. And this is done through the budget.
You have noted a number of things on which we are completely in agreement.
There is a need for more flexibility.
Obviously, we need to find together a capacity to have a much more flexible budget. Because it is the needs, it is the reactivity of Europe that is at stake.
It is also, of course, about setting priorities and organizing the efficiency of the European budget.
We will all agree on this. All agree. It is a necessity.
But where we need to be clear between us is that we need to have a calendar. We need to set together objectives, Mr. Commissioner. It can't remain only words, only commitments,
These texts are very interesting and I share them 100% But now we must get into the concrete and in particular on an essential question around which we are working, which is the clean resources
How can we do to have clean resources for Europe tomorrow? Not only for Europe, but for all European citizens and to find together the path of growth and a stronger path for Europe tomorrow.
It's up to you, Mr. Speaker.
Thank you Mr President. I would like to focus my speech on the preparation of the next G20 summit.

Everything has been said by the previous speakers on European economic governance, on the need to strengthen European economic governance, to strengthen the pact of stability and growth, and to better associate the European Parliament and of course also the national parliaments to the process.
I would like to quote two challenges that are being posed to our nations and to the G20 members and that should be addressed in the next G20 meetings.
the challenge of the war of currencies and the one of the volatility of the prices of raw materials.
I think that these two issues are real threats to global growth and cause very important imbalances on our planet.

to organize, to stop common positions, to give themselves the means to speak in one voice during the next G20 summit, Seoul but also those who will follow and more globally on the global stage. Thank you.
Thank you Mr President. My dear colleagues, I would like to congratulate our colleague Diogo Feio for the quality of the report and for the ambitious proposal it contains.
This also shows that the European Parliament takes its place in a debate that is decisive for the future of Europe and we can only benefit from it.
Moreover, the Greek crisis was a revelatory of the malfunctions that undermine the economic governance of the European Union.
I take note of the proposal of Mr. Feillot to establish a permanent mechanism for financial stability
We must also address the root problem
For this, I think that the solution also lies in the reinforcement of the pact of stability and growth, and in particular sanctions
It is essential if we want a sustainable sanitation of the budgetary situation of the States, which is not always popular,
It's restrictive, but we have no choice.

I think the report shows well the challenges that the marine environment represents in terms of fishing, aquaculture, transport, tourism, energy, mineral and biological wealth, research combined with climate change.
It is a considerable potential for development that should be secured, protected and put into practice for a long time, because the future of humanity depends on it.
The report also notes, and rightly so, that the European Union is the world's leading maritime power and that its ultra-peripheral regions offer it the largest exclusive economic zone in the world.
given such a statement. It is therefore the European Union's responsibility to implement an ambitious policy, a great policy of the sea.
If it is not the first maritime power in the world that does it, who will do it in its place?
But it is important to note that the resolution does not go very far in this direction.
It is not with 50 million euros that we can claim to occupy the place of leadership in global politics.
Finally, while the ultra-peripheral regions have a strategic position recognized, since present in all oceans,
It was fair to make them play a major role in a great strategy of the oceans, which unfortunately was not retained by the report and I regret it. Thank you Mr. President.
Madam Commissioner, I would like to return to the anti-contraband agreement that is currently being negotiated, especially with the United States.
This agreement also raises questions in the United States, especially among the officials of the American Office of the Brevets.
In addition, 75 American professors of law have just sent a letter to President Obama
They judge that ACTA, simple executive agreement, would be contrary to the American constitution.
While the European Parliament is preparing, as you know, to adopt a resolution on the ACTA agreement, this one still raises great concerns and is far from being unanimous.
to our fellow citizens, I think it would be useful to have from our American interlocutors a very clear answer. On two points, can ACTA be ratified by the United States?
Is ACTA a voluntary or restrictive agreement?
Indeed, an anti-contraband agreement, which is already absent, China, India and Brazil, which would not be implemented by the United States, would greatly lose its credibility.
Thank you.

Thank you Mr. President. Throughout this difficult birth of the Directive on Alternative Funds, I have not ceased to plead for the principle of equality of treatment between fund managers, whether they are from the European Union or not.
This principle sounds good as an evidence, but its devidence has come across numerous difficulties.
The result presented to us today is satisfactory in nature,
I thank the negotiators and especially our reporter Mr. Gauz√®s who, after this particularly painful birth, would deserve a substantial maternity leave.
I would like to emphasize that the issue of the treatment of third-country countries must be observed in two ways, whether we are inside or outside the European Union.
thanks in particular to the European Parliament, all funds that will be sold in the European Union will be subject to a comparable regulation.
We can more or less talk about Love's playing field

It remains that during the transitional period non-European entities will benefit from the national placement regime, while the EU funds and managers will be subject to the directive, which is generally stricter,

The situation is different on the markets that are outside the European Union. There, the European funds and their managers will remain subject to the directive, which is not the case for the third country funds.
It will be much harder to sell European products in the rest of the world because they will be less flexible and more cultured
We must be aware of this disadvantage, even if it was for a inevitable cause.

Regarding the depositors, we must also know that we will make the exercise more restrictive, especially because of the new responsibilities that will encompass them. Their purchase should lead to substantial modifications to the profession

I do not say this to show my opposition, but to indicate that this new regulation has nothing to do with our DIN. Its implementation, which is necessary, will also bring about difficulties, of which we must be aware.

Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, particularly in this beginning of the 21st century, patients need appropriate information in order to be fully involved in the healthcare process, to know where to look for care, to decide on the best treatment in accordance with health professionals and to follow the treatment planned.
Today, patients are demanding independent, comparative and adapted information for everyone's needs.
Unfortunately, the revision proposals of the directive submitted by the European Commission did not meet the needs expressed by European citizens.
These proposals opened the door to direct promotion by pharmaceutical companies, which seems to us to be nonsense in terms of response to the real needs of patients.
This operation has no interest for citizens or member states
On the contrary, it means an additional bureaucracy, an increase in expenses and taking risks for patients.
For these reasons, we first presented a rejection proposal of these texts, asking the Commission to review its copy

This approach, also adopted by my colleague Karl Schilter of the Group of Greens, allowed our rapporteur, Mr. Fechner, whom I salute, to proceed with an important revision of the Commission's proposals.

In parallel, we have also issued 60 amendments aiming to protect the health of our citizens and facilitate access to patients and independent information that is comparative and adapted to everyone's needs.

The adoption of these amendments in the Environment Commission has allowed us to focus more on the rights of patients to information rather than making the provision of information an option for pharmaceutical industries.

In light of the amendments and the compromises made, we have decided to withdraw our position of rejection of the texts and the substance of the texts, which have evolved in a good direction over the last few months.
The proposed report, as modified, has managed to counterbalance the initial proposals of the European Commission.

However, we will continue to refuse that health professionals can be instrumentalized to distribute brochures and information to their patients provided by pharmaceutical companies without any control of health authorities.
We will also oppose the authorization of industrial information campaigns, especially in vaccination.
Information can't come freely from pharmaceutical companies.

The experience shows that we must be very vigilant and, moreover, and I conclude, what happened with the Mediator drugs shows how much we must be vigilant and ensure that this point of balance, as we have sought it with this report project,

Thank you Mr. President, Madam Commissioner, Madam Minister. Union and realism will be declined, at least I wish so, during the vote tomorrow of our resolution on this 16th Conference of the parties on climate change.

I hope that our Commissioner in charge will be able to carry out the pragmatic objectives that we must achieve collectively, but also to defend the sine qua non conditions posed by Europe which are associated with it.
In these negotiations, we will also not lose sight of the legitimate expectations of our fellow citizens and our industries.
It is the world that must fight climate change and not Europe alone.
Thus, recognizing the importance of an intellectual property protected too little will be essential.
Green technologies must benefit the greatest number, but we must not, for the same time, waste our knowledge, present and future, and this, even for this indispensable fight against climate change.

Similarly, asking for common emission calculation methods, as well as verifying and publishing data, so that all the emitting industries are subject to the same bargaining chip, seems to be a legitimate and not a negotiation weapon.
Finally, more controversial, and my colleague raised it earlier, the gaps in the current system of clean development mechanisms will also be put on the table.
Dear colleagues, we are all well aware, regrettably, that the real force of negotiation is not held by the European Parliament.
But the will of many European MPs, of which I am one, to work and to participate in a positive outcome of this conference must be encouraged and not neglected, as we have felt these last few days.
If Europe wants to be strong in international dialogues, it must be the same for all its legislators.
Thank you, Madam President. The European Union often presents economic partnership agreements as a chance for African countries.
Also, does she despair not to see these agreements signed as soon as possible?
But the question that is asking us is why these countries are not rushing to sign agreements that would be so favorable to them.
Obviously, the appreciations differ on the quality of these agreements. And as long as these divergences of appreciation will persist, the ACP countries will be reluctant to sign them.
Wouldn't it be better to go further in dialogue and understanding by listening to the concerns and expectations of the ACP countries?
They want to talk about development strategies, while Europe often responds only with the opening of markets.
This is the kind of listening that the Parliamentary Parliamentary Assembly imposes on these European peacekeepers.
I think that other European bodies should proceed in the same way if we want to build a real strategic partnership between Africa and the European Union.
Thank you. Christians are probably one of the most persecuted religious groups in the world.

In the Middle East, they are perceived by certain extremist groups as, and I quote, legitimate targets. And the objective is their pure and simple departure from this region. A region where Christianity was born and in which their historical presence is necessary for a certain balance.
The events of the Baghdad Cathedral are only the culmination of a situation that we have observed passively for far too long.
The European Union, as a global actor and commercial partner of many countries in this region, must express its strong indignation in view of the situation.
Discrimination, whatever it is, cannot be tolerated.
Democracy will not be victorious in this region unless the most fundamental human rights, such as religious freedom, are respected.
We are all overwhelmed by the serious crisis that currently reigns in Ivory Coast.

It is obvious that the decision of the constitutional council of this country to question the electoral code in violation of the electoral code, the results of the elections officially proclaimed by the electoral independent commission, is unanimously condemned by the international community.
the European Union, the UN, the African Union, the European Union-ACP parliamentary assembly, the ECOWAS and soon certainly the European Parliament, demand the respect of the official proclamation

the election results and the establishment of the new President of the Republic, as recognized by the Independent Electoral Commission. The Independent Electoral Commission, which I recall, is an institution validated by the UN.
All the political groups of the European Parliament expressed in a joint statement their agreement on these essential points.

They also called for a stop to all escalation of tensions in the country that could lead to civil war, which would be for the Ivory Coast a human, social and economic disaster, which must be avoided at all costs.

Thank you, Madam President. I would like to thank our four rapporteurs who have done a remarkable job and who have brought an important added value to the European Parliament in the texts proposed initially by the Commission.
The citizen initiative that we are preparing for the PPP to vote with enthusiasm is a major advance of the Lisbon Treaty.
Let's not be fooled by it. This instrument can really change the European political landscape. For some, it can be used with both responsibility and audacity.
it can contribute to bring the European citizens to the fore directly in the European political debate.
it can contribute to bring about a European public opinion, that is to say, men and women, citizens of Europe, who debate together, who take positions together and gather on truly European issues.
But let's not disappoint our fellow citizens.
Let's urge our Member States to take measures quickly, where necessary. Let's not disappoint our fellow citizens. We must reinforce European democracy.
Thank you Mr President. I would like to, like many of our colleagues, address the persecution of Christians all over the world, especially Christians from the East.
We don't need to recall the recent horrible acts perpetrated.
I would like to remind you that defending Christians in the East as in the world, pleading for religious freedom, the diversity of the Christian community,
is to plead for freedom, democracy and human rights, values at the heart of the European project and which are, of course, universal values.
It is really time now, beyond indignation, emotion, solemn condemnations, of course, it is really time now to speak to the acts.
I call on the European Union authorities, the High Representative for Foreign Affairs and Security Policy, but also all our governors, the ministers of foreign affairs,
to engage in precise measures, to set up a concrete action plan to respect religious diversity and fight against all forms of religious persecution. Thank you.
Mr President, my dear colleagues, Madam High Representative, We all agree that the situation in the Sahel region has deteriorated considerably.
and letting a zone of unlawful access to Europe be established is a danger that we must fight firmly and without waiting.
extremist groups multiply and threaten the lives of civilian populations.
In my turn, I mourn human life losses and hostages and worry about European immigrants on the spot.
Until now, Morocco was a rampart against all kinds of traffic from the Sahel.
Now drug traffickers, weapons or human beings are going around Morocco, passing through Mauritania to the Canary Islands, heading for the European Union.
It is the responsibility of the European Union to act to help these states put an end to these threats.
Europe's security is at stake in our territory, but also in its direct neighbors.
It is time for us to act and I ask the Commission and the Council to implement an action plan to help the return to safety in the Sahel.
I am not a fan of the words of the Egyptian Tunisian people, but I am a supporter of the words of the Egyptian Tunisian people.
It represents a symbol of hope for all defenders of freedom.
A thought also for the victims.

I would now like to say that the European Union, which, as we have said, has been noticed by its lack of reaction, must be on the side of the Tunisian and Egyptian peoples to help them to bring about the opening of their country to reforms and to establish democracy.

The European Union has decided to support Tunisian leaders to engage in a peaceful transition, prepare the organization of future elections to gain freedom and allow the Tunisian people to find prosperity, development and social peace, an economy that will allow youth to find employment.

I would like to conclude by saying that the Union for the Mediterranean has an important challenge to face because the Jasmine Revolution has triggered a wave in all the states of the Maghreb, the Middle East and the Middle East.
It must set up a strong strategy against these countries.
But beware, in the face of this legitimate democratic movement, Europe must find a balance between non-interference in internal affairs, support for legitimate aspirations of peoples and stability.
Commissioner, my colleagues have called it a matter of time

At a time when Europe is questioning a common strategy for its supply of raw materials and especially rare earths, we cannot neglect the immense potential that represents the intelligent valorization of our waste.

Strengthen European standards to improve the functioning of the collection lines. Remedy for the problem of leak or illegal export of dyes. Or, increase our collection objectives, but also must be at the heart of this legislation.
Let us not forget the main actor of the success or failure of this regulation, the consumer.
The responsibility of the citizen is crucial. If we want to implement effective legislation,
And to do this, my dear Karl-Heinz, the co-contribution, among other systems, has been revealed to be one of the most relevant tools.
Electric and electronic equipment manufacturers must obviously be involved more in the collection and recycling system, but we cannot disown the citizen when it comes to the waste he produces.
Our citizens must be actors and not spectators of European environmental policy.

Thank you Madam President, Mr President, Mr Commissioner. I would like to share the remark made by Mrs McGuinness about the fact that there is an essential link between the food and agricultural question.
The issue that concerns us is the increase in prices in foodstuffs, with the consequences it can have on a certain number of populations in the world, but also in Europe.
I would like to share a statement
The tendency to increase agricultural prices and raw materials is a tendency, for me, long and which will last for three essential reasons. Demographic evolution of the world and the increase

of the world population. Second element, the fact that we have entered, with global warming, in climatic alias that pose problems, whether it is drought, whether it is floods. And the third point, because the world is also developing,
with emerging countries, consumption levels are rising.
So the tension on agricultural markets and raw materials is a heavy trend.
It is aggravated by the volatility of prices. And the volatility of prices is a consequence of the financialization of the world economy.
And it is on this subject that we must also attack, if we want to, the issue of agriculture and food.

And to do this, what the Commissioner said is important. There are two elements. Yes, we need transparency on stocks. But we also need a public stock policy, both in Europe and in managing stocks on a global scale, particularly at the UN level.
Second, we need to regulate financial markets and financial speculation, particularly by refusing that the speculative volume has no connection with the physical quantities exchanged on the markets.

We cannot accept that speculators come to speculate on the food issue without taking into account the consequences it can have since it is about the food of the world and of humanity. And I end by saying
and that leads me to two major consequences. We need a strong European policy and we strategically reaffirm Europe's commitment to be a food and agricultural actor worldwide.

And secondly, we need to change our development policy to ensure that, on a global scale, and Europe is an actor, we invest again in agriculture because we will need all the agricultures to feed the world.
Madam President, Mr. Commissioner, As in 2008, the price of raw materials is rising on global markets,
we are only at 3% of the level of 2008.
The decline in production in some traditional export zones is due to climate change. The deterioration of cereals by the production of agro-fuel and the speculation
financial institutions that have had the effects of the rise are responsible for this situation, as are the reports of the FMI, the French authorities and, as the Commission also says.
The consequences of this new food crisis hit hard the 1.2 billion inhabitants in the world who live below 1.5 dollars.
Since October, 44 million additional people have joined these people who live below the poverty line.
Two days before the G20 meeting, what is Europe waiting for to take measures similar to those voted in the United States?
Since January 13, 2011, the US administration has demanded the limitation and transparency of the positions taken by the financial funds on the markets of raw materials.
This advance is the first step to counter the appetites of the speculators.
The impact is dramatic also for European farmers.
They are no longer able to feed their animals
Hundreds of jobs are on the run.
Five years ago wheat was worth 100 euros per ton. Today it is negotiated at nearly 300 euros.
The data has therefore completely changed.
The Commission demands that farmers adapt to the market signal. It would be good to inspire today to follow its own advice.
Faced with this crisis, the European Union cannot wait until 2014 to find solutions.
We must face the crisis and I propose three concrete actions.
First, the creation of stock in the cereal countries to provide farmers with subsidized prices immediately.
Secondly, the indexation of the prices of meat paid to farmers on the evolution of the course of food for cattle.
Thirdly, for 2011, a mechanism for transferring aid for the support of cereals to animal farms. Thank you.
Thank you Mr President. Are we ready in Europe to face a pandemic
The answer is yes, but there is a but
The 2009-2010 H1N1 flu episode showed us that each member state reacted on its own, without much coherence or even solidarity.

As a fictional reporter on this case, I think we should have made these observations, but above all, go further, be constructive, concrete for our citizens, which, it must be said, and it is what seems to me the most damaging, we have undoubtedly lost a little confidence in the public health messages.

The report of Mrs Rivasi, which will be voted tomorrow, takes into consideration these fundamental priorities which are, among others, the systematic reinforcement of cooperation between Member States, a better coordination with
European health institutions, a clarification of the roles of European risk management structures, an evaluation of vaccination strategies and communications implemented in Member States.
So it's a good report, I congratulate the reporter. Again, it is obvious that there is no letter of death left,
it is the responsibility of our Member States who keep the essential competences in the matter. It is therefore a real responsibility to take on behalf of our citizens.
Thank you Mr President. It is my turn to express my very vivid emotions after the murderous murder on March 2nd of the Pakistani minister in charge of the Christian minority, Mr Bhatti.
This terrorist-like murder follows many other murders of brave, tolerant, man-to-man, man-to-woman Pakistanis.
Once again, we call on the Pakistani government to shed light on this cowardly murder and to effectively protect the people threatened by the fanatical religious extremists.
And I think of course, first and foremost, but not only, of Mrs Sherry Raymond.
And I also wanted to ask all the competent institutions of the European Union to include in the negotiations
to prepare future cooperation agreements, in particular the cooperation agreement between the EU and Pakistan, a clause respecting religious freedom and respecting human rights. Thank you.
Mr President, with the crisis and the explosion of the real estate bubble and the credit, the Irish state had to intervene to support the banks.
The Irish public deficit and the budgetary savings accumulated by local and central administrations, and particularly by Social Security, was estimated at 32% of the GDP in 2010.

If the Irish government, which can hardly refinance itself with the markets, wants to access loans from the European Financial Stability Mechanism and the European Financial Stability Fund, it will have to respond to obligations for changes in social and fiscal order, while these areas are subsidized.
In our opinion, this is not antinomic.
As a doctor, I would say that in case of fever, it is useless to prescribe antipyretics blindly without trying to treat the cause.
In the event of the allocation of these funds, it is up to the State to proceed with financing these funds in order to fill its excessive deficit and to correct its previous errors.
This austerity plan should improve GDP by 10% over the next four years.

Similarly, a bank without a single penny in its life and private management will condition its personal loan to a guarantee of solvability. Similarly, the European Union can lend to Ireland on the basis of consolidated solvability.
Without simulating in its private management, the bank will encourage the individual to negotiate, for example, an increase in salary or borrow elsewhere.

This is why, respecting the subsidiarity, the European Union, based on a memorandum established with the FMI, considers that this solvability goes through the reduction of the minimum legal salary and an adjustment of the pension without exonerating itself from the fiscal measures
in Ireland to choose whether or not to implement these measures.

This is not the open door to EU interference in the areas of subsidiarity, which would allow, for example, to dangerously impose a minimum European salary, but a protection of the stability of the euro area through a process of mutual guarantee.

Of course, we should also protect Ireland, as well as other countries in difficulty, but not at any cost, especially the one of seeing an Unable State repaying its debt, thus weakening its citizens and those of the entire European Union.

Mr President, Mr Commissioner, dear colleagues, the eruption of the Icelandic volcano in April last year, and many of us have said it earlier, provided a painful illustration of the fragmentation and the low efficiency of the European sky.
Each of us in this hemicycle was directly involved
and 5 million of our fellow citizens have been stuck without real alternative transport solutions.
and one year after this exceptional event, new European measures are still in the works.

A first crisis exercise, you said it, Mr. Commissioner, linked to volcanic ash is expected on April 13 and 14, under the coordination of the ECOC of the OACI and DIATA, but it is essential that the ESA assumes a real leadership for a coordination of security measures at the European level.
It is certain that the information provided by the VACs in London and Toulouse must be refined using more modern technological means.
These data, as we saw last April, can be contradictory and can lead each member state to make decisions concerning the closure of their airspace, less motivated by information than by emotion.
In this context, the role of the AESA is essential to offer a harmonized interpretation of these data, as well as to ensure the centralization and good dissemination of information.
Beyond the information of the waves, the ESA must set up a mechanism to collect available data by closely associating member states, airlines and their pilots.
This centralization of information and coordination of all the stakeholders will avoid the chaos and inconsistencies that we witnessed last year
I expect the Commission to present concrete proposals with the ESA that will fully integrate into the realization of the European Unified Sky.
President, dear colleagues, this text is important.
It's not a revolution. We can't say that everything went wrong before and that everything is perfect now.
But nevertheless, it presents a number of major advances at this provisional stage of our work.
The main ones have in my opinion a better framework for remote sales and in particular on the Internet. And this is chapter 3. Because we must strengthen the rights of consumers in this area.
E-commerce is very useful. It widens the consumer's choice, it allows them to obtain the lowest prices and it also allows small and medium-sized businesses and artisans to find new outlets.
To advance in this area, it was necessary to do it in a truly European way, that is to say, on some very targeted points, to put in place a complete harmonization of the rights and duties of each.
Very concretely, it was necessary that an Italian customer who buys on a Belgian site or on a German site knows that from now on he will benefit from the same rights, the same protection,
This is what this directive will make possible.
This means that his delay of retraction will last 14 days everywhere in the Union.
This means that he will immediately know the total of what he will have to pay, without fear of a bad surprise afterwards.
This means that with a double click, it will verify its order correctly.
Obviously, all this will change some habits.
In many states, there are fine lines in national law that everyone is convinced are fundamental, while sometimes we don't even find a trace of them in neighboring countries.
But living together in Europe is learning to modify one's habits a little, in service of the community and in general interest.
Let's be clear, this text will still need to be improved and we will have to do it in the coming weeks with the Council and the Commission.
And I appreciated the openings that have been made in this regard.
But we have already done substantial work, thanks to our reporter Andr√©a Schwab, whom I warmly thank.
But the real result of this work is the fact that the amendments will be voted tomorrow by all political groups.
The trust of consumers in the internal market of the Union is very fragile.
We needed this political unanimity to preserve it and to hope to strengthen it.
Point number 7. After the first line, a first shot. Guarantee the respect of human rights and fundamental freedoms, in particular
freedom of speech and assembly, the right to manifest peacefully, and to listen and take into account the legitimate demands of the demonstrators and ensure their security.

Thank you Madam President, my dear colleagues, Mr. Commissioner. The open agreement between Europe and the United States is an advance, but it is only a step. A step that places Europe in the face of a dilemma.
The Commission for Transport and the Commission have highlighted it.
Either we accept a deal that will disfavor European companies, or we suspend the agreement and risk losing the benefits acquired since 2008.
Allow me to make a parallel with the licenses of private and professional pilots, a text that will be discussed before the summer, because the pilots I am part of are facing a dilemma.
The European Agency for Aerial Safety, which wants to harmonize licenses on European territory, will do so to the detriment of the 80 to 90 thousand general aviation pilots
directly concerned, some of which are holders of a single US license, and to the detriment, and this is important, of companies and jobs linked to this activity.
I would like to draw your attention to this project which has no security foundation.
There are 31 times fewer accidents in American license holders.

The objectives of the Basic Regulation text 216-2008 allow us to foresee a recognition and an equivalence of the licenses that we do not see the interest of waiting for hypothetical agreements pushed back in 2014.
Thus, I propose a very open agreement and invite you to come with me when I come to the Parliament to demonstrate that an American piloting license is quite safe.
Thank you, Madam President. At this stage of our debate, I will inevitably be forced to repeat or support some of the things that have been said previously.
