The question of the Parliament's spending interests me as well.
In this regard, I propose to hold the group sessions in Strasbourg rather than in Brussels. This would allow us to make our seat in the Parliament in Strasbourg profitable.
And since we want to make savings, I suggest other things, for example to remove the Friday's per diem from our colleagues, also the removal of the per diem for journalists,
Europe is attractive enough to not have to give a per diem to journalists.

Let us not hide behind the budgetary argument to appropriate an important issue that exceeds the budgetary control framework, and this although I salute the important work of Ville, our reporter, concerning this discharge.
Finally, since we are talking about economy, I also want us to moralize and to strengthen the indemnization system of the group of visitors sponsored.

I do not find it very moral and it gives a very bad image of our institution that the group's manager is paid in cash, in species, on the day of the visit without any work, no control of what the group has spent.
sometimes the sum allocated, I tell you, exceeds the amount of the actual expenses.

It would be logical that the groups send a debit to the pre-trial, to the service of visits, that they receive a statement from the Parliament on expenses, and that on a bank account, and that we pay the interest on presentation of the invoices actually paid, with a ceiling, of course. Thank you.
Thank you, Madam President. I would like to address the Commission and my colleagues. I salute the presence of the Council.
The question that arises today emerges from the management in 2011 of the Schengen space.

This is no longer the space of the five member states of the 1980s. On the contrary, it is a space that has continued to expand in recent years and which now has 25 states, including three non-members of the European Union.
Like all European policies, the Schengen cooperation must adapt to the reality it covers today, which is not the same as it was ten years ago.

It is in this sense that we must read the proposals of the Italian and French governments and the pragmatic and necessary responses brought today by the Commission in its communication on immigration.
The mutual trust between the parties in the Schengen space is certainly the cornerstone of Schengen cooperation.
But this trust is based on reciprocal obligations.
If one of the parties does not respect its obligations and creates calls for help, the whole system becomes defective.
It is therefore possible for other States to respond to this failure by establishing temporary and strictly controlled control of its borders.
In doing so, these defiant states will be clearly invited to better control their external borders.

Moreover, as presented by the Commission, these measures would fully respect the Sprint Schengen, as these controls would be reintroduced as a last resort and the decision would be made at the European level and not intergovernmental.
These measures will be closely linked to the long-term measures in the perspective of a common migratory policy.
It is essential to strengthen Frontex, to plan more solidarity to support states located on the outside borders,
The situation that the Mediterranean has experienced in recent years only puts into practice a gap in the Kishinegun.
In a few weeks, migrants from the Mediterranean have represented a significant percentage of the French annual immigration.
This acquis is not static, but must evolve.
I hope that these proposals will be quickly adopted to ensure the public a better management of our Schengen space and to ensure the security of our common external borders. Thank you.
Yes, Mr. President. The European Union has finally come to take sanctions against Syria.

So, Madam High Representative, what diplomatic options do you consider to avoid such a disaster?

Mrs Mathieu, one minute and a half. Thank you Mr President, Mrs Commissioner, dear colleagues. I would like to congratulate my colleague Carlos Coelho on this report on the work of Orfebre and I know it was very complicated.

whether it is police and judicial cooperation, data protection, visa policy and control of maritime or terrestrial air borders. The latest evaluations are very clear.

and we will all measure in this hemicycle the extent of this type of decision for the citizens concerned.

Thank you Mr President. In its Europe 2020 strategy, the European Union has set itself as an objective to make our economy greener and our transports more modern.
All European institutions have largely supported this objective, including the quasi-totality of Member States and our Parliament.

In this context, it is regrettable that since 2008, several Member States have used the new proposal of the Eurovignette Directive to empty the new proposal of the Eurovignette Directive and to block this file.

Today, however, thanks to the tenacity of our reporter, and I would like to salute here Sa√Ød El Khadraoui, thanks to his tenacity to that of fictional reporters in their negotiations with the Council, we finally have a compromise before us.

This text is much less ambitious than the initial proposal, but it will allow for the first time to put into practice the principle of the payer-polluter and to internalize external costs of transport such as noise or CO2 emissions.

For this euro-bill not to be a simple tax, but to contribute effectively to the improvement of transport in Europe, Member States are also encouraged to reinvest the money collected in the modernization of transport modes.
The Parliament has also succeeded in obtaining concrete ideas on the interoperability of the system of tolls, as well as stronger incentives for the use of less polluting heavy loads.

In order to remain consistent with the political objectives set by our institution, I sincerely hope that we will be able to adopt this compromise that was proposed to us in the second reading and thus open the way to a more sustainable transport policy. Thank you.

Mathieu Deminute. Welcome, Commissioner. Madame President, Madame and Messieurs the Commissioner, I would like to first of all to salute the efforts of our colleague Carlos Coelho on this very difficult case which required a lot of technicality, a lot of work and knowledge of the case.
The control of our common territory and our European borders is one of the most important issues we must face, and the technological tool is more than ever at the service of this challenge.
Indeed, for several years, we have been able to assist to an unprecedented development of European databases and the exchange of personal data.
What some call a digital tsunami should certainly be confirmed in the coming years.
The SIS, the BIS and the Eurodac are essential instruments today to ensure the safety of our European citizens.
Ensuring good operational management of these databases is therefore a major issue to which it is our responsibility to provide an effective response.

This answer is of course very delicate and Carlos Coelho had to face numerous legal, institutional, budgetary, political and technical obstacles and he still managed to write a balanced text that satisfies all the parties interested.
The creation of this network agency seems to be the best solution to ensure the internal security of Member States.
No other institution or agency could take care of the proper management of these information systems.
It will improve the management of existing information systems, offer better synergy between databases and integrate instruments that will be adopted in the future.
One of the most delicate questions asked on this case was the agency's position. Where should it be established?
Estonia and France are the only two countries that have applied for the position.
France already has in Strasbourg the Schengen information system, which it has been operating and managing since 1995. Consequently, it has a complete technical mastery.
Following the conclusion of the European Council of December 2003, which gave priority to the new member states, Estonia also wanted to receive the seat of this future agency.

It seems to me that the compromise found is very good. A kind of distribution of missions, I conclude, Madam President, was carried out by transferring the agency's headquarters to Tallinn, where the tasks of governance, strategy and design of the programs will be carried out.
The development and exploitation of systems will take place in Strasbourg
the cost-efficiency ratio is very balanced and this solution of compromise does not cause the centralized management of IT systems. Thank you, Mrs. President.

Thank you, Madam President, Madam Commissioner. First of all, I would like to thank our colleague Simon Busutil for the wonderful work he has accomplished.
These reflections have enriched the initial proposal and we can only congratulate it.
This report shows us an agency with a more adequate way of decoupling the missions that are assigned to it.
Recent events have shown us the need for closer cooperation between the European Union, member states and the support of a strong agency.
Frontex finally obtains the means to fulfill its missions.
By acquiring or renting its own equipment and benefiting from the services of its own border guards, it becomes more independent and very efficient.

New tasks are also assigned to it, such as the organization of voluntary returns or the processing of personal data, so that we can fight against trans-female crime while protecting fundamental rights.

This extension of the Frontex competence field gives us the means to consider and deal with migration issues through a global approach and not to confine ourselves to a simple mechanical management of borders.
I approve the possibility of exchanging personal data with other European agencies, including Europol.
Finally, the human dimension took its place in this relationship.
A strong recognition of human rights is guaranteed by the proposal to establish a consultative council within the agency.

I can only highlight this complete proposal which takes a step forward towards a healthy and responsible management of our external borders in a context where migration pressures are particularly strong and continue. Thank you.

Thank you Mr President. I would like to thank reporter Mr Meyer and the comments of my colleagues, sometimes critical, but this 2010 Activity Report is finally a great opportunity to talk about the Commission of Petitions, because it remains too unknown.
Yet it is the Commission, having a direct, sometimes physical, link with the citizen, that can assist itself in our debates.
It has undeniable legitimacy in the Parliament and a very long expertise thanks to its direct relationship with the citizen.
Indeed, any petitioner can go to Parliament and defend his rights in front of the Commission of Petitions.
We can also salute the serenity of the debates, despite the painful cases that are often treated.
This Commission represents Europe as it should be, listening to the problems of its citizens and working together to find solutions and protect them.
Unfortunately, the means of action and the means of weighing remain limited, especially on the environmental risk of projects that are sometimes almost completed.
But I also see it when it comes to defending specific cases, such as family rights or child rights in the event of divorce.
We will carry out a mission in November on this subject.
I also regret that the national authorities do not always hurry to bring us all the necessary information.
I would like to thank the European Commission for the research and verification work it is doing, even if it could sometimes go further in the search for truth.
I also want to thank the constructive work we are doing with the European mediator.
I call on the citizens to continue to request us through petitions as representatives directly elected
Our role will always be to preserve your interests in strict respect of European law.
Mr. President, Mr. Commissioner, I am pleased with this resolution on the non-stop service because it is our responsibility to remind it of the extreme emergency.
First of all, let's note that what was a priority yesterday remains even more important today.

The lack of reliable definitions and statistical indicators on the 100-zabrisme can prevent us from seeing the crisis that is helping the number of people living under the poverty threshold to go from 79 million in 2009 to 84 million in 2011.

Today, it is about making available to everyone our human and financial capacities in order to prevent new tragedies from happening.

Thank you Mr President. Mr Commissioner, Mr Minister, the number of poor and unemployed people in the European Union is constantly increasing
More than 43 million Europeans are threatened with food poverty.

Today, 6 member states want to end the food aid program without any replacement solution. Germany, Sweden, Denmark, the UK, the Netherlands and the Czech Republic.

The Greens are ready to work with you on long-term solutions. But as soon as millions of people depend on this system, we cannot let the food aid budget be divided by four.
The emergency is real.

If nothing is done by the end of the year, more than 300 million euros will be missing from the food bank and nothing guarantees that the national governments will be able to take the lead to fill this gap.
So it is a real question of solidarity between peoples.
Let's not let an irresponsible minority of governments deprive millions of Europeans of food because it is above all a matter of survival.

We must fundamentally change our way of producing in order to bring food production closer to the populations, especially the poorest who are and who also have the right to healthy and balanced food.
Only a really long Pact will allow us to ensure that fewer Europeans will need food aid.
The Council must come back to reason and let those in need to seek this vital help.
I am addressing in particular the future Danish government which will have the responsibility to ensure the presidency of the European Union from January.
was to return to reason. Is it necessary to have the emotions of the end in Europe to realize the imperious necessity to change logic?

When it comes to saving banks, the Council has found solutions, but when it comes to saving food banks, that's it, there's no one left. The Parliament said a strong word last time, human beings are more important than finance,
it is high time to reaffirm it
In any case, we will be very vigilant and we will not fail to renew our appeal in a constructive way.
Six Member States hold in their hands the fate of 18 million Europeans in need.
6 member states that claim to do neither more nor less than legal.
Juridicism is one thing, humanism and political choices are another.
How can we not express our anger towards those who remain deaf to the alarm sounds of the associations that help the most vulnerable?
And we, European deputies, representatives of all citizens, do we want a Europe where national selfishness fixes policies, where few cases of the emerging budgetary difficulties of states occur?
It is not a question of renationalizing this help.

No. Let's maintain this program, let's give it a stronger legal basis, but let's not let those who, in the immediate future, in 2012, count on this help in particularly difficult times of crisis. Thank you.

is no longer acceptable.

without taking into account the restructuring strategies of the companies that take advantage of it without examining the cost-benefit ratio of a policy, I repeat,
Thank you Mr President. The European mediator proceeds with brilliance to investigate complaints against institutions and organs of the European Union.

Few people find themselves there.

Thank you, Madam President. Professional mobility and growth, professional mobility and competitiveness of our European Union, these are the terms in which the subject of the day is posed.

but it is in terms of the path towards growth that the issue of increasing professional mobility arises.

which reminded that Member States should recognise the potential of the domestic market to boost growth and create jobs and should act to eliminate all obstacles to the completion of the domestic market.
The European Council of October 23 also set as one of the essential priorities to achieve a growth, I quote, intelligent, sustainable,
including the implementation of the 12 priority proposals of the Act for the Unique Market, the 12 proposals made by the Commission, as part of which the recognition of professional qualifications.

Professional mobility must therefore allow us not only to ensure, if we strengthen it, if we modernize it, if we improve the free movement of our compatriots within this market, but also to allow us to acquire, we hope, additional growth margins.

Thank you, Madam President. First of all, I would like to congratulate reporter Mr. Kaczmarek for his excellent work.

We must never hold back the commitments taken by the European Union in 2010, during the European Year of the Fight Against Poverty and Social Exclusion, and during the creation of the European Platform Against Poverty and Social Exclusion, to have a European framework for social and territorial cohesion.

We must make the European funds and the most disadvantaged aid programs sustainable, improve social protection, support local or national initiatives that develop services for the care of children, elderly and dependent people.
Poverty is a scourge to be fought at the horizontal level and it is now time to act to allow the poorest to get out of their precariousness.

And we must, as political officials, at the European, national and local level, take the necessary measures to ensure, without discrimination, access to housing, health care, justice, education, first-hand employment with a minimum income, which can be indexed according to the poverty rate of each member state.

The protection of personal data of third-country countries still differs considerably from European standards.

First of all, our fellow citizens want to find and consume more and more locally produced and seasonal food for health and quality reasons in particular.

President, dear colleagues, I express myself in the name of Maurice Pongard, rapporteur for the development commission on the report of Mr. Gallagher.
It seemed important to me to remind that when a country wants to sanction a country that practices non-durable fishing, it must take into account its level of development.

Indeed, in the name of the principle of political coherence with the objectives of development, it is crucial, in my opinion, that the measures adopted in the field of fishing do not question the plans and development strategies set up by the European Union in these countries.
The report project of Mr. Gallagher takes up this important idea for our development commission, foreseeing that the measures should not be unjustified or even discriminatory.

I therefore invite the European Commission, when it adopts such measures, to respect this principle of coherence of policies with the objectives of development and that the level of development and vulnerability of countries be taken into account. Thank you.
This third reform of the fishing policy should not be done again against the interests of fishermen.

No, all fishermen are not these sea-pullers, the only ones responsible for the poor state of health of the stocks, as they claim, by encompassing all the fishing categories of environmentalist organizations and the European Commission.

Of course, we must preserve fish stocks, but we must also allow our fishermen to live off their activities and preserve the economic fabric, the dynamism and the cultural identity of our coastal regions.
However, the main measures of the European Executive go once again in the direction of the decrease in the number of fishermen to achieve the mythical maximum sustainable yield
I remind you that the French fleet has decreased by more than 50% since 1980.

The Commission proposes the implementation of transferable individual quotas, the guarantee of industrialization and the concentration of the sector, or the total ban on rejections, which professionals consider unrealistic.
This reform project will probably be suitable for the industrial fleet, but in the state it would mean the programmed death of what remains of local and craft fishing.

Thank you Mr. President. Mr. Commissioner, dear colleagues, I would like to thank Charles Gorenz for his excellent report.
We all know that the European Union provides more than half of the total of public aid for development worldwide. However, as of 2015, even if some objectives seem
we must ask ourselves the question of how to improve our aid, to make it more consistent with our commercial policy, with our agricultural policy, with our foreign policy.
The future of European development policy must rely on precise, measurable commitments and according to a short and medium-term calendar.

The economic crisis, climate change, the power of emerging countries, the land looting force us to define new priorities. Priorities to ensure food security, access to energy resources and access to health care.

A European consensus does exist, but we must rethink the European and international institutional systems in environmental and social matters, by using organizations that work on a decision-making level, such as the OMC.
Finally and above all, we must explain to our fellow citizens that the development of third-country countries is not only charity and solidarity, but also a source of development for us.
Just look at the markets that are opening for Europeans in emerging countries, China, Brazil and India.
2015 will also be an opportunity to better take into account the geostrategic evolution of the last few years, because the emerging countries of today were, not long ago, developing countries.
Now, as an essential economic power, these countries must also contribute to international aid.
The European Union must promote responsible development aid at the European and international level.

The year 2015 will be more than a deadline, it will be a unique opportunity to rethink the aid to development, not as a simple financial assistance, but as the support for responsible development projects, both at the social and environmental level.

I join my colleagues from other groups, the Economic and Social Committee and the Regional Committee, to ask that 2015 be designated as the European Year of Development and above all, a responsible development.
Thank you Mr. President. The agenda for the change proposed by the Commission raises, in my opinion, many questions, the main being the concrete implementation of the principle of differentiation.

The Commission hopes that, from 2014, the choice of countries in which the European Union will invest its help in development will be based on the mechanical application of the simple criterion of wealth per inhabitant.
As Mrs Ashton has said, these issues are not only of an accounting order, but they deserve a real political debate on the definition of our priorities in international cooperation.
Moreover, this differentiated approach does not, in my opinion, conform to the spirit of the Cotonou Agreement.

I am convinced that the ACP countries that have achieved positive economic performance must be encouraged in their transition to a more sustainable growth. These countries should not be indiscriminately sanctioned for the fact that they have managed to guarantee growth thanks to discipline, good governance and prudent economic policies.
